story:
Overview

 

A man is riding his new bike down a jagged street in New Orleans as the fresh memories of his near death experience from Covid 19 spin with the wheels. A woman on a Swedish island is painting a bustling crowd on canvas, somehow feeling their companionship from her empty home.  A mother in South Africa is coming home from the market, taking her mask off as she greets her three children at the door. These stories are true. These stories are happening right as you read this. These people, like so many, have been torn apart by the global pandemic. They've been torn apart by fear. But, unlike most, they have been pieced back together in an epic tapestry of stories evoked from around the world.

This is their story. This is YOUR story. It's the story of circumventing the fear of Covid 19 that is holding humanity frozen and frenzied, and turning circumstances into opportunities. This is the story of people from around the world as they take part in a 40 day challenge to reach their personalized goals, leaving them better than before and finding a sense of community along the way.

 

About

 

This is my story as well... as I’m the challenge creator who brought us all together for this 40 day experience. I’m Jess, a storyteller and filmmaker who went from a bustling life in the big city to, after a terrible turn of events, a life of solitude in a cabin deep in the wilderness. 

At least it was solitude before people from around the world rose to the challenge and began sharing their experiences, their vulnerabilities, and a palpable sense of purpose and empowerment no border can contain. My life is now humbled. My days are fulfilled. My mission has become sharing these inspiring stories to as many people as possible so they, too, can experience the truth, perseverance, and sheer magnitude of the human spirit that blows my mind every day.

I want everyone to see it… starting with you. I want you to finally have some good news in this jarring world we inhabit. I want you to see what’s possible when we forget our differences long enough to remember we’re all the same. I want you to see people truly giving their goals their all despite the insanity of a worldwide pandemic… and find out what they are really made of. Come help us show the world an epic tapestry of meaningful stories that chronicle the global experience of this pandemic.

 

Cast

 

As we are still filming the challenge, the cast is subject to change. Here's a sample of the types of stories you'll embark on when watching the show. 

  • Berkley-- New Orleans musician goes from a tough break to nearly broken after contracting and almost dying from Covid 19. 
  • Ghaireyah- South African muslim and single mother of 3 pushes through the quarantine while somehow still pursuing her passions of writing and comedy. 
  • Helen-- French CEO manages to maintain her integrity while swimming in the shark tank of business... only to experience a full burnout right as the quarantine began. 
  • Andrew/Missy-- Sailboat captain duo off the coast of California whose lives jolted to a halt as the wind left the sails of the tourism industry due to the pandemic. 
  • Brayan-- Go-getter and poet who road trips around the United States to find success. A conspiracy theorist at heart, he questions the answers with unique conclusions.
  • Francisco-- Out of work hairdresser in Brazil and member of the gay community who navigates living situations to find security while maintaining his side job of designing exotic dancer costumes.
  • Eva-- Swedish woman flees the city upon it's decision to take no action and let the virus run its course. She winds up in a cabin on an island where she is quarantined alone, despite being an extrovert at heart. 
  • Caitlin-- Out of work New York actor living in dangerous circumstances finds out she's pregnant unexpectedly... right at the beginning of the pandemic. 

 

... and there are many, many more stories to be shared.

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

This 40 day challenge began with 40 participants from around the world who come from a wide range of locations, socioeconomic backgrounds and professions. This means we have quite the adventure in store as we piece together a show that involves multiple factors. So we are going to put in the work and resources to make this beautiful collage of stories mix together nicely by hiring top notch resources, helping this show become a full length docu-series comparable to what you might find on Netflix, The shooting of the show has been going since April and will be completed in June, so the majority of the expenses now lie in post production.

Here’s the breakdown for the industry standard post production costs in order to create an 8 episode show in 5 months with 230 hours of footage:

  • Editor (Including color, sound, graphics, exports) 
  • Assistant Editor
  • Post Production Producer/Director (Including dailys, post supervision, coordination)
  • Executive Producer/Director (Including development to post storyline production)
  • Storyline Producer
  • Miscellaneous (Marketing design, trailer, music, tech equipment, debts, hard drives)
  • Contingency
  • Follow up film crews (Covering conclusion interviews, establishing shots, cinematic footage)

 

= $230,000 Total

 

With this fundraiser, the more you give, the more you get! We have several levels of unique perks that are available to you. Some are classic, some are personalized and multicultural, and some include on screen involvement in our project that you’ll never forget!  Check out the prizes in the perks list on the right.

 

Just in case...

 

More good news is as this is an Indiegogo campaign, your contribution can help us even in the chance that we don’t hit our goal. Every donation will still be used for getting us the best editors, producers, marketing materials and overall completed show possible.  If we find we don’t have enough to complete the show from this campaign, all resources will go into marketing and sponsor hunting so we can get the money we need with a different strategy.

However, if we DO get picked up by a network who will handle paying for everything, all money raised by this campaign will directly go back to the communities of those involved to help them and their loved ones get through the pandemic.

Either way, we are doing whatever it takes to get this show completed and every penny you put into it helps make this or even directly helping those impacted most by Covid 19 possible.

 

The Impact

 

This show is different than most shows. Not only are we capturing the history of a global covid 19 phenomenon from many perspectives in many cultures, but we are making a difference towards a better world wide future in the process. This show humanizes the judged, humbles the extravagant, turns stereotypes on their heads, and digs deep into the pure truth of the human experience in a way modern media has lost the ability to. 

We ask questions that challenge beliefs, show what can be possible despite the setbacks, and open an opportunity for the cast, production crew, and viewers to decide what our new post Covid 19 world could be. This show is more than a show. It’s a chance to take a break from the raucous of modern politics and news to experience rare authenticity and honesty that advances humanity a step closer to what it was meant to be.

 

Experience / The Team

 

Rumble Productions 

We have produced over 50 shows and entertainment experiences, been hired to develop shows for conventions, state fairs, entertainment organizations and corporate groups, performing for thousands in the process, and produced nearly 20 short films, resulting in our work getting featured in multiple film festivals. In addition to show creation, Rumble has provided personalized workshops and motivational challenges since 2016, which emphasize overcoming circumstances to become the best version of yourself, developing adaptability, and tapping into a deep innovation and creativity worthy of uncovering. These workshops and experiences have been presented at acting academies, private events, and hired for multi million dollar corporations alike.

See Rumbleabq.com for show and workshop reviews, testimonials and press history.

 

Jessica Wachs-- Executive Producer / Director 

 

My experience in the fields of show creation, hosting, film, cultural relations, and motivational challenge development has nearly been constant throughout my adult life. After graduating with a bachelors in Intercultural Communication and Anthropology at the University of New Mexico, I began my award winning production company, Rumble Productions, in 2014.

My other experiences include a long history in motivational challenge development, which began in 2012 when I graduated from a rigorous leadership program and began creating my own workshops and challenges. I have also professionally worked in film both behind and in front of the camera since 2012, where I crewed such films and shows as Jane Got a Gun with Natalie Portman, Corporate Animals with Ed Helms, Cliffs of freedom by Van Ling, Better Call Saul, and most recently, the Mother Mary pilot with Rachel Bloom.

 

Carlos Montoya-- Producer / Assistant Director

 

Carlos is a film professional with membership in the Director’s Guild of America. Having spent the better part of the last Two decades working on sets, he has been involved in quite a bit. Projects ranging from blockbusters to passion projects dot his resume in various roles.  A native to New Mexico, Carlos has seen the film industry blossom in his hometown. However, he jumps at the chance to see the world. Having filmed From Los Angeles to Berlin, Carlos is always looking for an adventure. 

What Carlos brings to this project is the ability to see objectively while bearing in mind a final product. Film experience has not changed his viewpoint that every story is what you take away from it as a viewer. In addition to having been in production, Carlos was an actor in the Screen actors Guild. The ability to see the process from both sides lends an understanding to members on both sides of the camera.

CREDENTIALS:  Director’s Guild of America,  Screen Actors Guild of America

 

Panchali Saha--  Producer/Executive Assistant


Panchali is a Bengali-American film producer originally from the suburbs of Chicago, IL. She received her B.A. in Cinema Arts & Science with a concentration in producing from Columbia College Chicago. She worked as a production manager on Amazon Prime’s talk show BIBO Weekly. Before moving to Los Angeles to pursue her dream of producing documentaries. Here, Panchali received the opportunity to do a production development internship at Tremolo Productions, a documentary production house whose films included Oscar winning documentary 20 Feet from Stardom. Working with the producers at Tremolo and learning the ins and outs of the documentary world was the dream. And after learning all that she could, she came onto the exciting Out of the Woods project! When she’s not working on her next film, Panchali is on the prowl for rescue cats.

 

Rebekah Ayala-- Producer

 

Rebekah (Bex) Ayala has acted in, directed and produced various short films, commercials and dinner theater experiences in Northern California. Recently moved to Southern California, Rebekah continues to collaborate with fellow film makers and creatives. She is self educating and building her own film company, See Evil Productions, and has begun entering her work into film competitions, such as 15 Second Horror Films, where she has begun building a working relationship with the company directors. The self proclaimed "Joan of Art" has years of experience bringing teams together to achieve comedic and abstract pieces and will continue to do so no matter the location or state of nation.


Austin Gelfman-- Producer
 

Austin is tenacious and dedicated to anything he puts his mind to. He moved out to LA after working for a production company in New York to pursue acting. He has been studying acting for three years straight at places like Lesly Khan, Annie Grindlay, Second City, and Groundlings. While in study, he has directed and produced many film and theatrical productions including a live theatrical variety show, many indie shorts, and the world premiere of a Hollywood Fringe musical. He has been working with people to create quality footage for over a decade in New Jersey, New York, and now Los Angeles and is extremely proud of the Out of the Woods project.

 

Risks and Challenges

 

Unpredictability: There are a few risks and challenges that come hand in hand with a project of this nature. First, the project itself is, while still structured, unpredictable in nature. We don’t know which participants will remain in the challenge, what they'll do or what circumstances may pop up as we are working with many strangers who are in unusual and often dangerous environments due to the pandemic. Fortunately, we are stemming from a production company that literally teaches workshops on improvising and adaptability corporately, so we are capable of adapting quickly to meet every need and have a top notch communicative team that helps each other if the ball gets dropped.

We also had a “test run” with a slightly shorter prototype challenge that is structured similarly and made for very identical circumstances, which occurred between March and April, 2020 at the start of the US quarantine. This test run resulted in us bringing on 40 participants to start the film as the expectation was that at least 20 would not make it through the challenge (we still have over 20 participants, however). 

 

Drastic culture differences/locations: Another risk is having so many people on board who are from so many different cultural backgrounds. Language, personalities, cultural needs, time zones, levels of danger in their living situation, and overall risk varies from person to person. So, keeping a group such as this uniform, up to date with the prompts and side challenges, on board with technology, out of harms way to the best of our ability, and with the spotlight of attention they each deserve is a challenge.

To counter this risk, we brought on four experienced, patient and supportive producers who each oversee 25% of the participants and communicate amongst each other in order to ensure the highest quality experience for everyone involved. We have been arranging translations, meeting everyone where they were at with technology, adapting to various needs, and keeping an eye on the progress and depth of each storyline and experience involved. No participant has been left behind save for those who opted out. No producer is left behind, either, as we care for the production teams needs just as fervently as we are all handling the same pandemic. 

 

Post production necessities: One thing that could be problematic is we have dozens of different stories interwoven with dozens of different cameras, mics, lighting set ups and technologies involved. This requires extra care during editing with extra color and sound mixing, potentially extra pick up and redo shots, and even more interviews after the original challenge to make sure there are no holes in the storylines. Making this look and sound great while making sure it all makes sense will be a hefty but worthy experience in order for this show to succeed. So we need funding at the industry standard level. 

To counter this risk, we are taking four completely different fundraising approaches. One is we are having the indiegogo for the full price and informing the media in many involved cities to get enough recognition to hit our donation goal. We are also preparing a top notch pitch package to approach already funded networks, approaching celebrities to get their involvement so we have more safety nets in place, investigating available grants or non profits who value the motivational, cultural and motivational worlds.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Any dollar, peso, euro and pound helps and would be extremely appreciated! But we also totally understand that this time is a time that is difficult to spend money. We all have basic needs to worry about. 

However, you can still help without spending a thing! We are looking to get the word out as quickly and loudly as possible as we have a lot to save in just 60 days. Just sharing our fundraiser on social media and emailing it around would do wonders for us. If you have the connections, reaching out to journalists, tv stations, magazines, online periodicals, celebrities, investors or philanthropists would be extremely helpful as well!

The more noise this campaign makes, the more people we can help with our message worldwide! Just use the Indiegogo share tools available and you’ll have contributed immensely! THANK YOU for your support and stay safe out there!
story_txt:
Overview

 
A man is riding his new bike down a jagged street in New Orleans as the fresh memories of his near death experience from Covid 19 spin with the wheels. A woman on a Swedish island is painting a bustling crowd on canvas, somehow feeling their companionship from her empty home.  A mother in South Africa is coming home from the market, taking her mask off as she greets her three children at the door. These stories are true. These stories are happening right as you read this. These people, like so many, have been torn apart by the global pandemic. They've been torn apart by fear. But, unlike most, they have been pieced back together in an epic tapestry of stories evoked from around the world.
This is their story. This is YOUR story. It's the story of circumventing the fear of Covid 19 that is holding humanity frozen and frenzied, and turning circumstances into opportunities. This is the story of people from around the world as they take part in a 40 day challenge to reach their personalized goals, leaving them better than before and finding a sense of community along the way.
 
About
 
This is my story as well... as I’m the challenge creator who brought us all together for this 40 day experience. I’m Jess, a storyteller and filmmaker who went from a bustling life in the big city to, after a terrible turn of events, a life of solitude in a cabin deep in the wilderness. 
At least it was solitude before people from around the world rose to the challenge and began sharing their experiences, their vulnerabilities, and a palpable sense of purpose and empowerment no border can contain. My life is now humbled. My days are fulfilled. My mission has become sharing these inspiring stories to as many people as possible so they, too, can experience the truth, perseverance, and sheer magnitude of the human spirit that blows my mind every day.
I want everyone to see it… starting with you. I want you to finally have some good news in this jarring world we inhabit. I want you to see what’s possible when we forget our differences long enough to remember we’re all the same. I want you to see people truly giving their goals their all despite the insanity of a worldwide pandemic… and find out what they are really made of. Come help us show the world an epic tapestry of meaningful stories that chronicle the global experience of this pandemic.
 
Cast
 
As we are still filming the challenge, the cast is subject to change. Here's a sample of the types of stories you'll embark on when watching the show. 


Berkley-- New Orleans musician goes from a tough break to nearly broken after contracting and almost dying from Covid 19. 

Ghaireyah- South African muslim and single mother of 3 pushes through the quarantine while somehow still pursuing her passions of writing and comedy. 

Helen-- French CEO manages to maintain her integrity while swimming in the shark tank of business... only to experience a full burnout right as the quarantine began. 

Andrew/Missy-- Sailboat captain duo off the coast of California whose lives jolted to a halt as the wind left the sails of the tourism industry due to the pandemic. 

Brayan-- Go-getter and poet who road trips around the United States to find success. A conspiracy theorist at heart, he questions the answers with unique conclusions.

Francisco-- Out of work hairdresser in Brazil and member of the gay community who navigates living situations to find security while maintaining his side job of designing exotic dancer costumes.

Eva-- Swedish woman flees the city upon it's decision to take no action and let the virus run its course. She winds up in a cabin on an island where she is quarantined alone, despite being an extrovert at heart. 

Caitlin-- Out of work New York actor living in dangerous circumstances finds out she's pregnant unexpectedly... right at the beginning of the pandemic. 

 
... and there are many, many more stories to be shared.
 
What We Need & What You Get
 
This 40 day challenge began with 40 participants from around the world who come from a wide range of locations, socioeconomic backgrounds and professions. This means we have quite the adventure in store as we piece together a show that involves multiple factors. So we are going to put in the work and resources to make this beautiful collage of stories mix together nicely by hiring top notch resources, helping this show become a full length docu-series comparable to what you might find on Netflix, The shooting of the show has been going since April and will be completed in June, so the majority of the expenses now lie in post production.
Here’s the breakdown for the industry standard post production costs in order to create an 8 episode show in 5 months with 230 hours of footage:


Editor (Including color, sound, graphics, exports) 
Assistant Editor
Post Production Producer/Director (Including dailys, post supervision, coordination)
Executive Producer/Director (Including development to post storyline production)
Storyline Producer
Miscellaneous (Marketing design, trailer, music, tech equipment, debts, hard drives)
Contingency
Follow up film crews (Covering conclusion interviews, establishing shots, cinematic footage)

 
= $230,000 Total
 
With this fundraiser, the more you give, the more you get! We have several levels of unique perks that are available to you. Some are classic, some are personalized and multicultural, and some include on screen involvement in our project that you’ll never forget!  Check out the prizes in the perks list on the right.
 
Just in case...
 
More good news is as this is an Indiegogo campaign, your contribution can help us even in the chance that we don’t hit our goal. Every donation will still be used for getting us the best editors, producers, marketing materials and overall completed show possible.  If we find we don’t have enough to complete the show from this campaign, all resources will go into marketing and sponsor hunting so we can get the money we need with a different strategy.
However, if we DO get picked up by a network who will handle paying for everything, all money raised by this campaign will directly go back to the communities of those involved to help them and their loved ones get through the pandemic.
Either way, we are doing whatever it takes to get this show completed and every penny you put into it helps make this or even directly helping those impacted most by Covid 19 possible.
 
The Impact
 
This show is different than most shows. Not only are we capturing the history of a global covid 19 phenomenon from many perspectives in many cultures, but we are making a difference towards a better world wide future in the process. This show humanizes the judged, humbles the extravagant, turns stereotypes on their heads, and digs deep into the pure truth of the human experience in a way modern media has lost the ability to. 
We ask questions that challenge beliefs, show what can be possible despite the setbacks, and open an opportunity for the cast, production crew, and viewers to decide what our new post Covid 19 world could be. This show is more than a show. It’s a chance to take a break from the raucous of modern politics and news to experience rare authenticity and honesty that advances humanity a step closer to what it was meant to be.
 
Experience / The Team
 
Rumble Productions 
We have produced over 50 shows and entertainment experiences, been hired to develop shows for conventions, state fairs, entertainment organizations and corporate groups, performing for thousands in the process, and produced nearly 20 short films, resulting in our work getting featured in multiple film festivals. In addition to show creation, Rumble has provided personalized workshops and motivational challenges since 2016, which emphasize overcoming circumstances to become the best version of yourself, developing adaptability, and tapping into a deep innovation and creativity worthy of uncovering. These workshops and experiences have been presented at acting academies, private events, and hired for multi million dollar corporations alike.
See Rumbleabq.com for show and workshop reviews, testimonials and press history.
 
Jessica Wachs-- Executive Producer / Director 
 
My experience in the fields of show creation, hosting, film, cultural relations, and motivational challenge development has nearly been constant throughout my adult life. After graduating with a bachelors in Intercultural Communication and Anthropology at the University of New Mexico, I began my award winning production company, Rumble Productions, in 2014.
My other experiences include a long history in motivational challenge development, which began in 2012 when I graduated from a rigorous leadership program and began creating my own workshops and challenges. I have also professionally worked in film both behind and in front of the camera since 2012, where I crewed such films and shows as Jane Got a Gun with Natalie Portman, Corporate Animals with Ed Helms, Cliffs of freedom by Van Ling, Better Call Saul, and most recently, the Mother Mary pilot with Rachel Bloom.
 
Carlos Montoya-- Producer / Assistant Director
 
Carlos is a film professional with membership in the Director’s Guild of America. Having spent the better part of the last Two decades working on sets, he has been involved in quite a bit. Projects ranging from blockbusters to passion projects dot his resume in various roles.  A native to New Mexico, Carlos has seen the film industry blossom in his hometown. However, he jumps at the chance to see the world. Having filmed From Los Angeles to Berlin, Carlos is always looking for an adventure. 
What Carlos brings to this project is the ability to see objectively while bearing in mind a final product. Film experience has not changed his viewpoint that every story is what you take away from it as a viewer. In addition to having been in production, Carlos was an actor in the Screen actors Guild. The ability to see the process from both sides lends an understanding to members on both sides of the camera.
CREDENTIALS:  Director’s Guild of America,  Screen Actors Guild of America
 
Panchali Saha--  Producer/Executive Assistant
Panchali is a Bengali-American film producer originally from the suburbs of Chicago, IL. She received her B.A. in Cinema Arts & Science with a concentration in producing from Columbia College Chicago. She worked as a production manager on Amazon Prime’s talk show BIBO Weekly. Before moving to Los Angeles to pursue her dream of producing documentaries. Here, Panchali received the opportunity to do a production development internship at Tremolo Productions, a documentary production house whose films included Oscar winning documentary 20 Feet from Stardom. Working with the producers at Tremolo and learning the ins and outs of the documentary world was the dream. And after learning all that she could, she came onto the exciting Out of the Woods project! When she’s not working on her next film, Panchali is on the prowl for rescue cats.
 
Rebekah Ayala-- Producer
 
Rebekah (Bex) Ayala has acted in, directed and produced various short films, commercials and dinner theater experiences in Northern California. Recently moved to Southern California, Rebekah continues to collaborate with fellow film makers and creatives. She is self educating and building her own film company, See Evil Productions, and has begun entering her work into film competitions, such as 15 Second Horror Films, where she has begun building a working relationship with the company directors. The self proclaimed "Joan of Art" has years of experience bringing teams together to achieve comedic and abstract pieces and will continue to do so no matter the location or state of nation.
Austin Gelfman-- Producer 
Austin is tenacious and dedicated to anything he puts his mind to. He moved out to LA after working for a production company in New York to pursue acting. He has been studying acting for three years straight at places like Lesly Khan, Annie Grindlay, Second City, and Groundlings. While in study, he has directed and produced many film and theatrical productions including a live theatrical variety show, many indie shorts, and the world premiere of a Hollywood Fringe musical. He has been working with people to create quality footage for over a decade in New Jersey, New York, and now Los Angeles and is extremely proud of the Out of the Woods project.
 

Risks and Challenges
 
Unpredictability: There are a few risks and challenges that come hand in hand with a project of this nature. First, the project itself is, while still structured, unpredictable in nature. We don’t know which participants will remain in the challenge, what they'll do or what circumstances may pop up as we are working with many strangers who are in unusual and often dangerous environments due to the pandemic. Fortunately, we are stemming from a production company that literally teaches workshops on improvising and adaptability corporately, so we are capable of adapting quickly to meet every need and have a top notch communicative team that helps each other if the ball gets dropped.
We also had a “test run” with a slightly shorter prototype challenge that is structured similarly and made for very identical circumstances, which occurred between March and April, 2020 at the start of the US quarantine. This test run resulted in us bringing on 40 participants to start the film as the expectation was that at least 20 would not make it through the challenge (we still have over 20 participants, however).  Drastic culture differences/locations: Another risk is having so many people on board who are from so many different cultural backgrounds. Language, personalities, cultural needs, time zones, levels of danger in their living situation, and overall risk varies from person to person. So, keeping a group such as this uniform, up to date with the prompts and side challenges, on board with technology, out of harms way to the best of our ability, and with the spotlight of attention they each deserve is a challenge.
To counter this risk, we brought on four experienced, patient and supportive producers who each oversee 25% of the participants and communicate amongst each other in order to ensure the highest quality experience for everyone involved. We have been arranging translations, meeting everyone where they were at with technology, adapting to various needs, and keeping an eye on the progress and depth of each storyline and experience involved. No participant has been left behind save for those who opted out. No producer is left behind, either, as we care for the production teams needs just as fervently as we are all handling the same pandemic.  Post production necessities: One thing that could be problematic is we have dozens of different stories interwoven with dozens of different cameras, mics, lighting set ups and technologies involved. This requires extra care during editing with extra color and sound mixing, potentially extra pick up and redo shots, and even more interviews after the original challenge to make sure there are no holes in the storylines. Making this look and sound great while making sure it all makes sense will be a hefty but worthy experience in order for this show to succeed. So we need funding at the industry standard level. 
To counter this risk, we are taking four completely different fundraising approaches. One is we are having the indiegogo for the full price and informing the media in many involved cities to get enough recognition to hit our donation goal. We are also preparing a top notch pitch package to approach already funded networks, approaching celebrities to get their involvement so we have more safety nets in place, investigating available grants or non profits who value the motivational, cultural and motivational worlds. Other Ways You Can Help
 
Any dollar, peso, euro and pound helps and would be extremely appreciated! But we also totally understand that this time is a time that is difficult to spend money. We all have basic needs to worry about. 
However, you can still help without spending a thing! We are looking to get the word out as quickly and loudly as possible as we have a lot to save in just 60 days. Just sharing our fundraiser on social media and emailing it around would do wonders for us. If you have the connections, reaching out to journalists, tv stations, magazines, online periodicals, celebrities, investors or philanthropists would be extremely helpful as well!
The more noise this campaign makes, the more people we can help with our message worldwide! Just use the Indiegogo share tools available and you’ll have contributed immensely! THANK YOU for your support and stay safe out there!

story:
Overview

I’m Allison Waxman, a third-year MFA candidate in the Writing and Producing for Television program at Loyola Marymount University. Full Count is my graduate thesis project and I’m aiming to raise $7,000 to fund the production and post-production process

 

About Full Count

Full Count is a comedy series about the fictional, down-on-their-luck, Triple-A ball club, Morro Bay Otters and former child-actor psychologist Sasha Roth, who is brought in to turn them around. In desperate need of a change of scenery, Sasha’s tasked with fixing hot-headed All-Star, Landon Casey, who’s made it his mission to make Sasha’s life a living hell. This adds insult to injury for General Manager Peyton Mesoraco, Sasha’s former best friend, whose job is on the line. Sasha is forced to act fast before the truth about why she was let go from her last job is revealed.

 

What We Need

There’s still a lot left to pay for before production even begins. Some of the expenses left to cover are:

 

-Locations: Because of the magnitude of the project, we need to have a baseball stadium capable of passing as a minor league stadium. That means looking at current and former minor league stadiums and collegiate stadiums, with rental fees totaling well over $2000.

 

-Uniforms and Props: Jerseys, hats, bats, balls, helmets, gloves, you name it, we need it. While our location is being gracious enough to allow us to use the larger items like batting cages, we need the smaller items, which adds up at the end of the day.

 

-Catering and Craft Services: Most of my crew and cast members are helping me on a volunteer-basis. The least I can do is make sure they’re well-fed and hydrated.

 

And much more!

 

Risks & Challenges

With any outdoor production, there's always the risk of weather and rain. While it's always sunshine and warmth here in California, January tends to be the rainy season.

I have a number of productions under my belt during my time here at LMU and have learned a lot along my way. As a result, I've learned to prepare. We have a rain draft of our script. We also have a contingency in our budget in case of weather. Our location is being gracious enough, once again, to work with us in case mother nature decides to do her thing.

 

Meet the Team

 

Allison Waxman - Writer-Creator-Executive Producer

Unfortunately a New York Mets fan since birth, Allison was born and raised ON (you’re never in) Long Island, NY. Allison was keen on working in Sports Management, then in English Education, then in Public Relations and Advertising and then back in English Education again, but the one thing that stayed consistent was her love of television and film. She continued to write an array of pilots during her array of potential career choices and soon realized what she needed to do. After graduating from Hofstra University with a degree in Video and Television Production, Allison moved to Los Angeles to pursue her MFA in Writing and Producing at Loyola Marymount University’s School of Film and Television. She’s excited and beyond anxious to bring her love of sports and television together.

 

Liz Holland - Director

Liz Holland is a Los Angeles native who graduated from Loyola Marymount University in 2018 with bachelor’s degrees in Film & Television Production and English Literature, and a minor in Film & Television Studies. Since graduating, Liz has produced and assistant directed numerous projects, including independent shorts, commercial advertisements for CocaCola RegalFilms, series streaming on Funny or Die (The Room Actors: Where Are They Now) and Netflix (The Hollywood Masters Series), as well as four feature films. Over the past three years she has directed two shorts, the first, “Blue Dream,” was accepted into the Chicago International Blow Up Film Festival in 2017. The most recent, “Rough Cut,” is just now hitting the festival circuit, being screened at HollyShorts Monthly and awarded at Blow Up 2019. With over five years of production experience and the LMU School of Film and Television Undergraduate Production Award, Liz is an active and avid member of the film community, passionate about collaborating and creating.

 

Patrick Kelly - Producer

Patrick was born in Newton, MA. He grew up in North Carolina and Massachusetts before studying theater at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. After graduation, Patrick was distraught to discover that his theater degree didn’t open as many employment-related doors as he had hoped. During this time, Patrick wrote a bunch of screenplays while working at a nonprofit after-school program for at-risk kids. After burying his first few screenplays in the yard (yes, they were THAT bad), he continued writing until he managed to option a pilot with a producer. Nowadays, he’s pursuing an MFA at Loyola Marymount University’s School of Film and Television.

 


Preston Ray - Producer

Preston Ray grew up in Oklahoma City, a place where there is truly nothing to do. As a way of entertaining himself and his friends, he turned to filmmaking and started churning out a series of cringeworthy videos that are preserved for posterity on YouTube. After discovering this passion for making movies he attended The University of Texas at Austin where he was able to make a few more films and write a few scripts. Now as a graduate student of LMU’s Writing and Producing for Television MFA program, his ambitions have broadened beyond the realm of YouTube videos as he tries to bring bigger and better stories to the screen. A retired little league slugger himself, he is extremely excited to see Allison’s story of a minor league team be brought to life.

 

Noura Alavi - Associate Producer

Like the legend that is Beyonce, Noura was born and raised in Houston, TX. After bouncing around from studying Classical Archaeology (???) and International Relations, Noura graduated from The University of Texas with a BA in Psychology. During her time at UT, Noura took a number of creative writing courses which greatly increased her passion for storytelling. Not quite brave enough to veer off course after graduation, Noura worked as a research associate in a Clinical Psychology Research Lab specializing in Anxiety Disorders. Although contributing to important research, Noura felt unfulfilled in her work and finally decided to pursue her lifelong passion for writing and filmmaking. Noura is now pursuing an MFA in Writing and Producing for Television at Loyola Marymount University. A complete novice to the beautiful game, Noura is looking forward to being properly educated on all things baseball.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! The best way for people can find out about the project is by hearing from people already excited to see the finished product!

story:
Series Plot (season 1)

With Gotham City torn apart by corrupt police officers, politicians and organized crime, Bruce Wayne returns to Gotham to wage war on crime. But in the wake of a hurricane, a new face emerges to black out the city and test the minds of Gotham's citizens.
story_txt:
Series Plot (season 1)
With Gotham City torn apart by corrupt police officers, politicians and organized crime, Bruce Wayne returns to Gotham to wage war on crime. But in the wake of a hurricane, a new face emerges to black out the city and test the minds of Gotham's citizens.

story:
After a run in with a voodoo priestess as a child, Marcus Downer is convinced he is cursed with bad luck. Developing a series of spell breaking rituals and totems since his 9th birthday, Marcus has become accustomed to a life of mishaps well into adulthood. As a fresh start, the aspiring screenwriter leaves Chicago for California to pursue a career in film and television. Life in Los Angeles, however, is not turning out as Marcus had imagined. On his 29th birthday, after performing his usual mock voodoo ritual, he hits a wall of misfortune that forces him to confront his past, take control of his life and rid of this curse for good.


We, the creator and producer of JU-ju, a comedy about a young man overcoming seemingly insurmountable obstacles to pursue his dreams, need your help in bringing this story to the screen.

We're looking to raise money to produce a show that will make you all laugh and feel a part of our journey throughout Season 1. With our teaser above, 8 written scripts and your help, we believe we can bring this hilarious story to life! 

Join us by helping to fund this hilarious project. We've got the promotional trailer and eight side splittingly funny scripts ALREADY WRITTEN. We need your help getting this story filmed and distributed to the world. We're asking you all to help us make our $60,000 goal. Here's the intel on where your money will go:

  • The $60,000 we raise here will go toward our small but awesome independent film crew - actors, producers, cinematographers, sound mixers and set designers - who have mastered the ability to be nimble and cost effective without sacrificing quality.
  • The money will also cover production costs like: legal services, locations, wardrobe, make-up, equipment rentals, marketing, distribution and festival submissions.

In return, we've got some dope perks for you! Check out the list to the right that offers everything from a special thank you to attending the LA Premiere with us!

Don't you fret, if you're able to support financially or not, word of mouth is as good as gold. Know that every time you spread the word we make this show more and more possible. 


Mysticism is a part of the African American narrative. The last time we can remember seeing brown faces and the concept of JU-ju was in Eve's Bayou, a favorite film of our producer's. The creator of JU-ju comes from a lineage that migrated from the Gulf of Mexico to Chicago and with his familial heritage and extensive research, we've been able to put together an authentic depiction of a serious spiritual practice in a hilarious way. 

If you haven't noticed, the show logo for JU-ju is very 90s. In fact, it's absolutely inspired by the hit 90s sitcom, Martin. One of our aims is to give you a modern version of the boldness of that era: colors, shapes, lighting style and even some new takes on classic scenes.

The creator of JU-ju grew up completely enamored with sketch comedy of the 90s, from In Living Color to Mad TV. In JU-ju he brings these larger than life, ridiculous characters that color the show throughout each encounter and he fully commits as the protagonist of the story in what, at times, is very physical comedy. Some of the best parts of filming were completely improvised as our creator pulled from his network of performers from The Second City where he performed weekly for a time. While the script was the guide, as director, he allowed them to bring their improv sensibilities to their characters and play with lines in a way that would really take the comedy over the edge.

 

     

    As with most things in life, there are risks and challenges. In the case of JU-ju, the only risk is putting ourselves out in the world creatively for others to judge and critique. Any other risks are in our minds. Of course, there's the anxiety of whether or not we'll make our goal but, the way we see it? There's more anxiety in never trying a thing at all. 

    One of the challenges that come with crowdfunding and creating this show is maintaining clarity of vision. In the writer's room, we are pulling together people from different backgrounds and experiences to tell a story that is uniquely African American AND universal at the same time. In that process, we have to maintain the reality of who our crazy characters are within a world that still feels real to the viewer. Now, we know this doesn't sound much like a challenge, but everyone has a different writing style and interesting realities that we have to corral and make sure are in line with  message behind this kind of story. A story that is supernatural without being superhero.

    We're also challenged by the misconceptions people have about African American stories and whether they are relatable to non-African Americans.  To that, we say, to be human is universal. To chase something you want badly is universal. To fail repeatedly at something is universal for all who try something bigger then themselves. To get out of your own head is a universal practice. Comedy is universal. LAUGHTER is universal.

    *steps off Iyanla soapbox*

    Basically, everyone will see themselves in this story but yes, it's important that African Americans recognize the small things that we've inserted as well. 

     


    Jason Mimms is from the South Side of Chicago and the creator/star of JU-ju. His most prominent theatrical  performances include Robey Theatre Company’s Knock Me A Kiss and The Magnificent Dunbar Hotel and he is best known for his film and television roles in Laff Tracks, Boy Bye, Almost Nowhere and Hell Date.

    Mimms earned his bachelor’s degree in theatre arts from Clark Atlanta University and is a member of the Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity. He is a part of an exclusive community of actors from the  Chicago Theatre Company - once a prestigious association in the South Side community - where he was mentored by Peter Chatman at the age of 10 throughout his tenure at Mt. Carmel High School.
     


    Lauren F. Ellis is a Visual Effects Executive Producer and founder of Finding Freddie Media, LLC from Alexandria, VA. She has been credited in a number of hit television shows including Queen Sugar, The Affair, Shooter, Ballers and film Fruitvale Station. Ellis earned her master’s of fine arts from the Academy of Art University and her bachelor’s in print journalism from Hampton University. She is also a member of the Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc.

    JU-ju is the flagship webseries produced by Finding Freddie Media.

     

    We're excited to have you on this journey with us!

    *Special thank you to the cast and crew of our JU-ju concept trailer and KO Creative for cutting it together for us. Shout out to Fields of Gold Productions for shooting our behind the scenes interviews and to Kesniel Akalaonu for editing*
story_txt:
After a run in with a voodoo priestess as a child, Marcus Downer is convinced he is cursed with bad luck. Developing a series of spell breaking rituals and totems since his 9th birthday, Marcus has become accustomed to a life of mishaps well into adulthood. As a fresh start, the aspiring screenwriter leaves Chicago for California to pursue a career in film and television. Life in Los Angeles, however, is not turning out as Marcus had imagined. On his 29th birthday, after performing his usual mock voodoo ritual, he hits a wall of misfortune that forces him to confront his past, take control of his life and rid of this curse for good.

We, the creator and producer of JU-ju, a comedy about a young man overcoming seemingly insurmountable obstacles to pursue his dreams, need your help in bringing this story to the screen.
We're looking to raise money to produce a show that will make you all laugh and feel a part of our journey throughout Season 1. With our teaser above, 8 written scripts and your help, we believe we can bring this hilarious story to life! 

Join us by helping to fund this hilarious project. We've got the promotional trailer and eight side splittingly funny scripts ALREADY WRITTEN. We need your help getting this story filmed and distributed to the world. We're asking you all to help us make our $60,000 goal. Here's the intel on where your money will go:

The $60,000 we raise here will go toward our small but awesome independent film crew - actors, producers, cinematographers, sound mixers and set designers - who have mastered the ability to be nimble and cost effective without sacrificing quality.
The money will also cover production costs like: legal services, locations, wardrobe, make-up, equipment rentals, marketing, distribution and festival submissions.

In return, we've got some dope perks for you! Check out the list to the right that offers everything from a special thank you to attending the LA Premiere with us!
Don't you fret, if you're able to support financially or not, word of mouth is as good as gold. Know that every time you spread the word we make this show more and more possible. 


Mysticism is a part of the African American narrative. The last time we can remember seeing brown faces and the concept of JU-ju was in Eve's Bayou, a favorite film of our producer's. The creator of JU-ju comes from a lineage that migrated from the Gulf of Mexico to Chicago and with his familial heritage and extensive research, we've been able to put together an authentic depiction of a serious spiritual practice in a hilarious way. 
If you haven't noticed, the show logo for JU-ju is very 90s. In fact, it's absolutely inspired by the hit 90s sitcom, Martin. One of our aims is to give you a modern version of the boldness of that era: colors, shapes, lighting style and even some new takes on classic scenes.
The creator of JU-ju grew up completely enamored with sketch comedy of the 90s, from In Living Color to Mad TV. In JU-ju he brings these larger than life, ridiculous characters that color the show throughout each encounter and he fully commits as the protagonist of the story in what, at times, is very physical comedy. Some of the best parts of filming were completely improvised as our creator pulled from his network of performers from The Second City where he performed weekly for a time. While the script was the guide, as director, he allowed them to bring their improv sensibilities to their characters and play with lines in a way that would really take the comedy over the edge.




 




 
As with most things in life, there are risks and challenges. In the case of JU-ju, the only risk is putting ourselves out in the world creatively for others to judge and critique. Any other risks are in our minds. Of course, there's the anxiety of whether or not we'll make our goal but, the way we see it? There's more anxiety in never trying a thing at all. 
One of the challenges that come with crowdfunding and creating this show is maintaining clarity of vision. In the writer's room, we are pulling together people from different backgrounds and experiences to tell a story that is uniquely African American AND universal at the same time. In that process, we have to maintain the reality of who our crazy characters are within a world that still feels real to the viewer. Now, we know this doesn't sound much like a challenge, but everyone has a different writing style and interesting realities that we have to corral and make sure are in line with  message behind this kind of story. A story that is supernatural without being superhero.
We're also challenged by the misconceptions people have about African American stories and whether they are relatable to non-African Americans.  To that, we say, to be human is universal. To chase something you want badly is universal. To fail repeatedly at something is universal for all who try something bigger then themselves. To get out of your own head is a universal practice. Comedy is universal. LAUGHTER is universal.
*steps off Iyanla soapbox*
Basically, everyone will see themselves in this story but yes, it's important that African Americans recognize the small things that we've inserted as well. 

 

Jason Mimms is from the South Side of Chicago and the creator/star of JU-ju. His most prominent theatrical  performances include Robey Theatre Company’s Knock Me A Kiss and The Magnificent Dunbar Hotel and he is best known for his film and television roles in Laff Tracks, Boy Bye, Almost Nowhere and Hell Date.
Mimms earned his bachelor’s degree in theatre arts from Clark Atlanta University and is a member of the Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity. He is a part of an exclusive community of actors from the  Chicago Theatre Company - once a prestigious association in the South Side community - where he was mentored by Peter Chatman at the age of 10 throughout his tenure at Mt. Carmel High School. 

Lauren F. Ellis is a Visual Effects Executive Producer and founder of Finding Freddie Media, LLC from Alexandria, VA. She has been credited in a number of hit television shows including Queen Sugar, The Affair, Shooter, Ballers and film Fruitvale Station. Ellis earned her master’s of fine arts from the Academy of Art University and her bachelor’s in print journalism from Hampton University. She is also a member of the Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc.
JU-ju is the flagship webseries produced by Finding Freddie Media.
 

We're excited to have you on this journey with us!
*Special thank you to the cast and crew of our JU-ju concept trailer and KO Creative for cutting it together for us. Shout out to Fields of Gold Productions for shooting our behind the scenes interviews and to Kesniel Akalaonu for editing*

story:
Short Summary

The Working Title was first created by Eva Luna and Noah Bruckshen in August of 2016. It began as nothing more than a joke - the idea of a TV show about a boring, generic workplace, where one of the characters is a vampire and it's never really addressed. As conversations continued and the characters began to take form though, we realized that it had become much more than that. This was a full, well rounded story about people we had grown to really care about - and not only that, a story that it was important to us to tell.

It's impossible for us to tell it alone though.

UPDATE: The pilot is now available online here!

 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to make what we want to make, at the quality we feel it needs, it'll take us around $2,000 per episode. This comes out to $10,000 to make the rest of our first half a season, which is 5 more episodes. We realize this is a lot to ask for, which is why we've broken it down by episode. 

  • $2,000 - Episode 2: Like Oprah Always Says...
  • $4,000 - Episode 3: Sexual Harassment, if you Know What I Mean
  • $6,000 - Episode 4: Like a House Fire
  • $8,000 - Episode 5: Ghosts?
  • $10,000 - Episode 6: Sunday in the Park with Janine

This is our rough budget in order to afford props, costumes, camera/sound/lighting equipment, and the ability to make this a viable, sustainable project for our cast and crew. However much is raised through this campaign will determine how many episodes we are able to shoot.

 

Perks

$10 - Facebook/twitter shout-out -  We will personally thank you on our
Facebook or Twitter page, whichever you prefer

$30 - Digital copy of the script - Get the pilot script before it goes live online

$50 - Personalized thank you video - A video from your cast member of choice, personally thanking you for contributing

$75 - Early access Screening - Watch the pilot before it goes live online! We will email the video file directly to you!

$100 - Episode two preview - receive a digital copy of the first two pages of episode two - Like Oprah Always Says... Meet Janine, the boss, early!

$150 - A day on set - Spend two hours on set with our cast and crew during filming of our second or third episode in mid-August

$1000 - Executive Producer credit - exactly what it sounds like! Get listed in the credits of the first half of the season as an Executive Producer!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We're well aware that contributing monetarily isn't going to be possible for everyone. If you want to help us gain awareness but don't have the funds to help that way, you can help by

  • Following our facebook, twitter, or instagram accounts
  • Telling your friends and family about our show
  • Sharing this campaign page on social media

story:
Ayúdanos a hacer esta historia realidad

"¿Por qué no seguiste?" nació como un cortometraje que realizamos para demostrar nuestro apoyo a la comunidad LGBTQ+ por el día del orgullo en Lima. Jamás esperamos la acogida que tuvo y que se convierta en un éxito rotundo. Y todo gracias a ti. 

El cortometraje y la primera temporada fueron autofinanciados por Colectivo 360. Somos una agrupación de jóvenes pre-profesionales y no contamos con todos los medios para sacar adelante este proyecto. Esta vez queremos darte un mejor producto: capítulos con más duración y mejor calidad. Y necesitamos de tu ayuda para lograrlo.

PQNS2 contará la historia de Joaquín retomando los sucesos de la primera temporada. Sabremos a quién eligió y lo que le depara el futuro. También podremos conocer más de la historia del resto de personajes que queremos, así como nuevos rostros que entran a formar parte de esta gran historia. 

Este proyecto es muy importante para nosotros. Queremos seguir llevando la responsabilidad de representar y brindar visibilidad a la comunidad LGBTQ+, a través de esta historia de amor y tolerancia. Enseñando que todos somos humanos y todos tenemos derecho a amar.  

Sabemos que para ti también es importante este proyecto. Una vez más, te agradecemos por vernos y seguirnos. Todo esto es posible por ti. Y es por eso que recurrimos a ustedes: nuestros fans. Necesitamos de su ayuda para sacar adelante este hermoso proyecto. 

Con tu ayuda,  cubriremos la mayor parte de gastos de producción. El dinero que recaudemos irá destinado a cubrir los siguientes gastos: remunerar a los actores comprometidos con la serie, la seguridad, transporte, locaciones y alimentos para todo el equipo. Así como otras necesidades de las áreas de arte, fotografía y sonido. 

Finalmente, nos ayudará a contar con los mejores equipos profesionales para la realización y así obtener la mejor calidad de imagen. Para que obtengas un producto de alta calidad, como los que ves en televisión o en Netflix. 

Esto no es todo. La producción ha preparado lindas sorpresas y regalos para todos los que nos ayuden. Además, ¡podrás aparece en los créditos de la serie! Agradecemos tu donación desde lo más profundo de nuestros corazones. 

#PQNS sigue. Y tú, ¿te atreves a seguir?

 

*          *          *          *          *

Help us make this story possible

"You should've kept going" was born as a short film to give our support to the LGBTQ+ community for Pride in Lima, Peru. We never expected such amount of reception and succes that it got. And all thanks to you. 
 

The short film and the first season were self-funded by Colectivo 360. We are a group of pre-professional young adults and we don't have the meassures to make this proyect a reality. This time we want to give you a better product: longer episodes with better quality. And we need your help to achieve this. 

PQNS2 will tell Joaquín's story just where season 1 left things. You will find out who he chose and what's ahead of his future. You will also know more of the characters you love and new faces that will be a part of this great story. 

This proyect is very important to us. We want to keep the responsability of representing and giving visibilization of the LGBTQ+ community with this story of love and tolerance. Teaching that we are all humans and we all have the right to love. 
 

We know this proyect is important for you too. Once again, we thank you all for watching and following us. This is all because of you. And that's why we come to you: our beloved fans. We need your help to make true this beautiful proyect. 

With your help, we will cover most of the production spenses. The money we collect will cover the following things: actors and actresses remuneration, security, transport, locations and cattering for the whole team. Besides other needs from the deparments of art, photography and sound. 

Finally, it will help us get to work with the best professional equipment, so you can get the best image quality. That way you can get a higher quality product, just as the ones from TV or Netflix.

This is not all. Our production has prepared nice surprises and gifts for everyone that help us. Besides, you will appear in the series credits! We apreciate your donation from the bottom of our hearts. 

PQNS keeps going. Do you dare to keep going?

story:
Our plan for this TV series is to follow Arturo to different destinations around the globe to meet local musicians, explore the Universal Language and their cultural identities together, and bring the results home to you. The DEMO REEL will be shot in Abu Dhabi and will feature the musical traditions of Kuwaiti pearl divers...

 

 

“While a diver was diving, his friends on the boat would all sing a song for him,”  [...] “It would be his specific song, that was made up for him based on how long he could hold his breath under water.

“By the time the song was finished, if he hadn’t surfaced they would go in and rescue him. It was like a timer. They had no watches, so this song played the role of a stopwatch.”

The last pearl divers stopped working in the 1960s [...] there was a concern that much of the culture that accompanied their work – such as their songs – was in danger of being lost for ever.

 …and a variety of Middle Eastern/Arabian Gulf music and cultures as expressed and performed by trumpeter Yazz Ahmed,

the oudist Ali Obaid,

the Moroccan vocalist Malika Zarra,

 

and more!

The sizzle reel will feature Arturo rehearsing with these Artists, exchanging musical ideas, and ultimately performing together. In between those times, they may enjoy a meal together, walk through the streets of Abu Dhabi, and check out the local color. All in all, it is a picture of Arturo immersing himself (and you) in the Universal Language, Middle East/Arabian Gulf style.

 

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET

Our sizzle reel “Rhythms of Life: Abu Dhabi” is being developed in stages. The first stage, shooting the footage in Abu Dhabi, will cost about $19,000. When we have a rough assembly of that footage, we will move on to a second stage, which is all about editing the footage to create a beautiful, warm, and enjoyable program. Finally, the third stage is post production, which will involve the voice-over narration, music, and mixing.  For the first stage, which will be shot in February of 2019, we would greatly appreciate your help and support.

 

But wait there’s more! If you are able to help finance the shoot this coming February, we’re able to offer the following perks as tokens of our appreciation:

 

$5,000 and above – Executive Producer credit for sizzle reel, two tickets to an Arturo O'Farrill performance, lunch with Arturo, invitation to private screening reception in New York

$2,500 and above -  Associate Producer credit for sizzle reel, two tickets to an Arturo O'Farrill performance, invitation to private screening reception in New York

$1,000 and above – Co- Producer credit for sizzle reel, two tickets to an Arturo O'Farrill performance, invitation to private screening reception in New York

$500 and above – Benefactor credit for sizzle reel, CD and download of Arturo's latest album

$100 and above -  signed CD and download of Arturo's latest album

$25 and above – CD and download of Arturo's latest album

$10 and above – link to sneak preview and our genuine thanks for being a part of this project

$1 and above – you will be among the first to know the release date and where to find our show!

GET TO KNOW THE TEAM

Arturo O’Farrill, Principal Performer

Ahmed Lotfy, Producer (Abu Dhabi)

Fred Miller, Manager

 

Please help share this Indiegogo campaign on social media or email. Thank you so much for checking out this project, and for joining the campaign.

story:
The Story

City in a Jar is a web-series production following a set of characters through the night streets of Chicago in search of an ideology.  One part Political Thriller and two parts Existential Odyssey, the script languors in back alleys, but can turn on a dime.  There is no shortage of character either:  56 different people (from garden party democrats to anti-political grad students to an alt-right dishwasher) populate this expansive, 10 episode show.  And of course, the overwhelming question: what's up with Mara?  

-Synopsis:

Years after Hillary Clinton's 2016 presidential loss, a former volunteer to her campaign wanders Chicago in search of purpose. However, ties to her estranged family make her the target of a clandestine plot which aims to determine her future prospects.

It's a heady story and an examination of the Politicultural space we inhabit.  

Who We Are

My name is Jaryd Jensen. 

I'm an award winning filmmaker (Yes, So - Best Windy City Short, Blow Up International Film Festival) working and living in Chicago, and a graduate of Columbia College.  I've worked on numerous low budget ventures over the last 8 years in this city.  Each one exciting.  Each one teaching me more about film.  This project is especially dear to me as I've spent the last year developing and writing the script for it.  It is an ambitious journey, and without help, a daunting one.  But years of working on short films (directing and crewing) have reinforced the notion that a few people with a lot of talent and drive will always surprise you.

................................................................................................................................................................

Below is a list of people who can Actually can make things happen:

V. Kaci Sehr

was born in Chicago, Illinois, where she has lived most of her life. She has been writing, drawing, painting and telling stories for as long as she can remember. She has published a children’s book and is actively involved in theatrical events throughout the year.

 

Vaughn Walker

is an actor and musician living in Chicago.   He has been seen in both theater and film productions, most recently as the larger than life infomercial guru Phil Cranston, in The United States of Zombification.  Vaughn has worked with Jaryd on several productions since 2010 as an actor and a sound man.  His skills with a boom pole are Beyond Compare, and he is a fiercely proud trumpet player. 

 

Owen Newberry

has worked on six projects with Jaryd - including "Yes, So" and "Monster Myth." He has his Bachelor of Arts degree in Creative Writing with a minor in Psychology from Knox College and will be begin working on his masters in screen writing this fall. His favorite animal is the rabbit and has appeared as one onscreen.  And it was exactly as horrific as it might seem.  

 

Przemysław Bosak

is a composer and sound designer.  He has collaborated with several Chicago area theaters.  Movies with his original scores have been shown in festivals in Chicago, Las Vegas and San Diego, including the award winning “Yes, So” and “The Kowalski Test.”  Last year, an adaptation of “20,000 Leagues Under the Sea” he scored for the Chicago-based Strawdog Theatre was presented in Australia.  While not an Angelo Badalamenti, Przemysław has enjoyed fruitful collaborations with movie and theater directors, and is presently finishing the score for his first feature film.  As an avid fan of crime series, he is excited about scoring and acting in Jaryd’s project.

 

Mike Danovich

is an actor, writer, director and filmmaker based around Chicago. He has a few short films posted online that he worked on as a writer/director/cinematographer. If not behind the camera, Mike can be found in front of the camera as an actor or performing in shows around the city. He has been seen at Brown Paper Box, First Folio Theater, Theatre at the Center, and Apollo Theater. 

 

Caitlyn McCain

is a writer and proofreader. Originally from the East Coast, she's new to film and relatively new to Chicago, but enjoys discovering the world of both. She's a general all-around help: willing to edit, brainstorm, or drive crew around when need be. 

 

What the Money Does

Money, like time, water, and bagels, is a resource, and is necessary for certain areas of production.  So where does it go?

1.  Actors - The three main actors must give a lot of time for this show, and have a lot of heavy lifting in their roles.  These are nuanced characters who internalize quite a bit.  

2.  Location/Set Design - The second largest expense, as there is a set that must be built and a location that must be secured for it.  A large chicken wire cage filled with surveillance equipment housed in an empty office.  Not everything can be shot out in the cold.

3.  Equipment - Mostly sound equipment related (the easiest way to identify a low budget film is the sound).  We have recorders, cables, and various boom and studio mics, but not lav mics (the tiny hidden in your collar ones).  These are not expensive to rent, but it adds up.  Also batteries.  Batteries get expensive.

4.  Crew - Many folk donate their time to make a project like this happen, but there's not much better than getting paid for doing something you love.  Especially when it's hard work.

5.  Kraft - Kraft as in food.  Food as in bagels.  And lots and lots of Coffee.  

 

The Impact

People spend a lot of time on YouTube.  There are channels and content that are extremely popular: Buzzfeed, React compilations and derivations, Let's Players. And for a long time it was said that YouTube was a space for only low-engagement types of content. But the increasing popularity of political, philosophical, cultural, and otherwise educational content suggests that the interest of the audience is not so simple - and has actually been evolving.  There is a viewership, and it is growing.  And this viewership has a desire for perspective. 

This web-series is certainly ambitious (the total page count for the script is 149 pages).  But it tackles issues that are already discussed on the platform.  Online political debates have increased in popularity.  Right wing ideologues have found purchase.  Marxist cultural criticism is present on channels like ContraPoints and ZeroBooks.  Conversations about feminism, morality, postmodernism all have their audience on YouTube.  This web series can live in that space.  It opens up ways that we can talk through fiction.  Its ambition is in its scope and artistic perspective.  There is a very large cast of supporting characters, 50 total locations to truly make the show feel like an odyssey, and elements of documentary that are woven into the narrative with planned-for interviews in sections of the script.  So, the impact will be an artistic and narrative expansion of the types of content that can find a home on places like YouTube.  Scripted, artistic, relevant narrative.  On a modest budget.
