story:
Help Prevent Teen Suicide by Supporting My Life is Worth Living

I’m Gabe Alvarado. I created a non-profit foundation specifically to help prevent teen suicide. I am working with a team of world-renown animation storytellers and a team of suicide experts to create a powerful animated series called My Life is Worth Living. 

I approached the Wonder Media animation studio because they write powerful animated stories that affect change. My Life is Worth Living will be available FREE of charge 24 hours a day on YouTube and social media, where teenagers spend 85% of their time.

Suicide is the second leading cause of death for young people ages 13-17. In the last decade, hospital admissions for suicide attempts have doubled. I believe it is imperative to take action now! 

Our goal is to give at-risk teenagers hope by modeling what hope looks like, with characters and stories that ring true and are relatable. When a desperate teenager is sitting alone in a dark place our stories are intended to lead them out of the darkness and into the light.

This online initiative will provide a global platform capable of connecting and engaging teenagers in the conversation about suicide prevention while teaching important prevention skills. This will include skills like recognizing warning signs associated with suicidal behavior and how to reach out when you’re having suicidal thoughts.

We will launch the first iteration of this initiative nationwide on Suicide Prevention Day on September 10, 2020.

The Gabe Alvarado Foundation is a 501(c)(3) is an IRS-designated 501c3 non-profit. Tax ID #83-3831012.  All donations are wholly tax-deductible.

 

 
 

Gabe Alvarado's Story

Life can change in a flash. That moment for me was when I was injured in an explosion at the oil refinery where I worked. I lost my left arm and suffered burns on over 60% of my body both inside and out. The pain was so excruciating that I was in an induced coma for 90 days. After coming out of the coma, I was put on suicide watch due to the effects of trauma on my mind and body. But, when I started to recover I didn’t want to die. I realized that my life is worth living. It was at that moment that I came to realize my life’s purpose. I am here to give hope to anyone who might be considering suicide due to the effects of physical or emotional trauma. 

My story of hope after pain was used as the inspiration for the animated character in our series named Danny. He is a teenager who suffered severe burns saving his brother, Angel, from a house fire. Danny will be one of the many characters in the animated series we create to provide a guiding light for teenagers.  Angel will be one of the characters who demonstrates the ways to support loved ones who are experiencing suicidal thoughts.

By connecting with teens through animated characters and stories, we can empower them with lifelong skills to help themselves and others through dark times. We want to be a part of the solution! By speaking frankly and empathetically about suicide, we can give at-risk teens and the people in their lives the tools to recognize suicidal behavior.
 
My life was saved. I want to pay it back and use intentional animated stories to save the lives of others! 

 

This video explains why I want to use animation.

 

7 Reasons why My Life is Worth Living WILL help prevent teen suicide:

  1. Power of animation — Animation is a universal language that connects powerfully to young people. Teens are more likely to listen to and take advice from animated characters in relatable stories than from an adult giving them the same information.
  2. Use of social media — Teens today are more connected than ever, spending about 85% of their free time, or 60 hours per week, in front of a device. The animated series will meet them where they are on YouTube and social media.
  3. Free and available everywhere — The series will be made available online for FREE. This will allow us to reach teens in the moment they are struggling without any barriers to accessibility.
  4. Wonder Media successes — My partner, Wonder Media, has experienced huge success with an animated series to prevent child abuse called the Protect Yourself Rules. The series was produced for the Barbara Sinatra Children’s Center and has been viewed by over 200 million people and adopted by the United Nations, the National YMCA and the Boy Scouts of America.
  5. The experience of my team — The founder of Wonder Media, Terry Thoren, has over 40 years of animation producing experience. He was the former CEO of Klasky Csupo, Inc. the studio that incubated the Simpsons and produced Rugrats, The Wild Thornberrys and Rocket Power.
  6. Reviewed by experts — The series will be reviewed by doctors and teen suicide experts to ensure that the animated stories model the best practices in suicide prevention and that the strategies are research-based.
  7. My passion — My experience with physical and mental trauma has given me a passion to connect with teenagers to help prevent teen suicide.

 

 

My Plan

I need your help. No one can do it alone. In order to produce quality animation, I must work with expert producers, creative directors, voice talent, and writers. 

I will consider one life saved, and one family spared the pain of losing a loved one, a rich return on our investment.

It will be worth it.

Animated episodes on YouTube have the potential to reach millions of people! The Wonder Media team has produced content that has connected with billions of people worldwide. They know how to equip this generation with the tools to help them climb out of a dark place.

We need your help.

 

Why Wonder Media?

 

Wonder Media has also produced The Protect Yourself Rules and Stop the Secrets That Hurt with the Barbara Sinatra Children’s Center Foundation to fight child abuse. Those videos have been viewed by over 200 million people worldwide and The Boys Scouts of America now require every Cub Scout to view the series!

The Protect Yourself Rules and Stop the Secrets That Hurt videos have inspired children to talk about their abuse. You can scroll to the bottom of this campaign for examples of the comments and letters children have sent after viewing the videos on YouTube and how they were influenced by the stories they saw. We hope to have the same level of impact on teenagers experiencing thoughts of suicide.

Wonder Media is passionate about helping children in all stages of life. They also produced a series of animations for the Global Institute for Habits of Mind to teach children critical thinking skills like “managing impulsivity,” “thinking about your thinking,” and how to “listen with understanding and empathy.”  

The founder of Wonder Media, Terry Thoren, has over 40 years of animation producing experience. He was the former CEO of Klasky Csupo, Inc. the studio that incubated the Simpsons and produced Rugrats, The Wild Thornberrys and Rocket Power.

 

What We Need and What You Can Get

Every dollar donated to our cause humbles and amazes me. We have designed exciting packages for people who become a part of our team. Our favorite package is the Lifeline Package for $198. With the Lifeline Package, you will receive frame-able custom artwork, credits in an episode, a tote bag, a t-shirt, and early access to the episode animatics! Animatics are the preliminary version of an episode, using storyboards and soundtrack to visualize the story.

For larger donations—such as the Benefactor Package—you can be made into an animated character in My Life is Worth Living! However, we know that large donations aren’t feasible for every person and we truly and deeply appreciate each dollar that comes in for our mission — we thank you on behalf of teenagers whose lives we have the power to affect.  

What does an animated series cost? ……... What does it cost to build a house?

When people ask “What does an animated series cost?”, we think of it this way: “What does it cost to build a house?” The cost to build a house is dictated by the size of the house, the number of rooms, the size of the land, etc. The same is true of animation. The bigger the series, the more it costs to build.

Animation can be expensive. For example, Frozen II cost $1 million per minute of animation. But our goal is to keep production costs under $9500 per minute.

We plan to raise $50,000 to be used to develop new animated characters for the series, develop the world they live in, and then produce the first two episodes of My Life is Worth Living. We will then share these new episodes with global organizations who have the power to help us find the funding to produce a library of episodes.

 

The Production Plan

Your contribution will help take the series from the development stage all the way to the finished episodes. You can help us build this house! Here’s what the production process will look like:

Development:

  • We will create a library of characters
  • We will develop the world they live in while keeping social and cultural considerations in mind based on the statistics of teen suicide
  • We will create a series bible that will be reviewed by our suicide prevention experts to ensure that they align with best practices
  • We will write a treatment and script for each episode

Pre-Production:

  • 2D artists will create designs for each character
  • Storyboard artists will create storyboards as a scene by scene road-map for each episode
  • We will collaborate with a casting director to cast the right voice talent
  • Editors will combine storyboards with voice over to create an animatic for each episode
  • We will do test screenings with teenagers and prevention experts 
  • We will use feedback from our test screenings to make improvements in order to create the best episodes possible

Production:

  • Animators will create animation libraries for each character
  • 2D artists will design and create props for each character
  • 2D artists will design and create backgrounds for each scene
  • Animators will animate each character in each scene

Post-Production:

  • Editors will composite the animation with the backgrounds and props
  • Editors will create any visual effects needed to help tell each story
  • A composer will score and sound design the episode to enhance the world
  • Editors will combine the soundtrack with the scenes to complete the episodes

 

Stretch Goal

If the campaign reaches the goal and receives additional donations, that money will be used to produce additional episodes. Our hope is to create 10 episodes dedicated to self-help and 10 episodes dedicated to helping others. Anything raised past our initial fundraising goal, will go toward that larger endeavor!

 

The Team

Wonder Media is a mission-driven animation studio that is working with my foundation to produce My Life is Worth Living. Led by Terry Thoren and Ryan Cannon, Wonder Media is known for producing animation that has the power to change children’s lives. I approached them after the series they produced for the Barbara Sinatra Children’s Center Foundation reached over 200 million people worldwide. Terry Thoren is the former CEO of the company that produced Rugrats and The Wild Thornberrys. He has over 40 years of animation industry experience, and he has spent the last decade with Ryan creating animations with a purpose.

Dr. James Mazza and Dr. Jennifer Stuber are the suicide prevention experts on our team. Dr. Mazza has been a suicide researcher and expert for over twenty years—focusing specifically on teen suicide and the ways in which suicide can be prevented. Dr. Stuber has personal experience with suicide and now passionately works with University of Washington’s Forefront—a suicide prevention organization. Drs. Stuber and Mazza will ensure that the series is research-based with proven strategies for suicide prevention.

 

Our team has the power to be successful. But without your support, we will not be able to reach the millions of teens who will benefit from the lessons we will provide to them. No one can do it alone! Be a part of My Life Is Worth Living today.

***
 

Response to Animation:

Content below was taken directly from YouTube comments & hand-written letters in response to the Barbara Sinatra Children's Center Foundation series mentioned above. Formatting and spelling will vary.

Child #1 -- “I was child abused and I’m nine I’m sad my mom said to not tell anybody but hey this is a video about telling the truth and tell a parent and I did.”
 

Child #2 --“My name is Julia i got sexually abuse from my trusted person, My uncle he always come and visit dad and give me Xbox,ipad,phone he gave me everything i wanted but when months past hes starting to be..too touchy and i think that was fine and when he visit dad he would always hug me and, I feel like something was touching my boobs.. but i tho it was an accident and other months came when it was about my birthday i was on my bed drawing some cool animes and he came and give me presents he told me its advance presents, And he lock the door and did something i didin’t want too i wanna scream but i’m afride i felt so horrable from myself and gross to myself i wanna tell my parents but i was afride that i’ll break my family, I cant hardly sleep it was so hard cause i keep on thinking about it and i lost my friend, I just suddenly scream at them when i saw this about 6 weeks ago i told my dad.. and i want to share too you im 13 now and i was touch when i was 8 my uncle got arrested and.. i keep telling on myself why didin’t i just told my parents i wouldn’t have to face this on 4 years of my whole life. You made me feel better thank you {Fight Child Abuse}"

Child #3 -- “I would like to thank you for making such a great video. This is what pushed me to finally report my abuser. It took a lot of guts but I kept remembering how this video said that the abuse would stop after I reported it. I knew things would get better. I find it interesting that as we near the end of the year, its coming to the time where one year ago I reported that monster, and this video popped up in my recommended. Things are happier for me now, and its all thanks to you guys. I know you will probably never see this, but I write this in hopes that you do, and to anybody who is being abused, PLEASE report it. Even if you aren’t sure about whether or not its considered abuse, you should always report it to somebody who will take it seriously. Because most of the time it IS abuse.﻿”

Child #4 -- “please make more vids they help me. My life is hard. My dad is like that to me he abuses me and hits me and break things please your my only hope﻿”

What We Need and What You Can Get
Every dollar donated to our cause humbles and amazes me. We have designed exciting packages for people who become a part of our team. Our favorite package is the Lifeline Package for $198. With the Lifeline Package, you will receive frame-able custom artwork, credits in an episode, a tote bag, a t-shirt, and early access to the episode animatics! Animatics are the preliminary version of an episode, using storyboards and soundtrack to visualize the story.
For larger donations—such as the Benefactor Package—you can be made into an animated character in My Life is Worth Living! However, we know that large donations aren’t feasible for every person and we truly and deeply appreciate each dollar that comes in for our mission — we thank you on behalf of teenagers whose lives we have the power to affect.  

What does an animated series cost? ……... What does it cost to build a house?
When people ask “What does an animated series cost?”, we think of it this way: “What does it cost to build a house?” The cost to build a house is dictated by the size of the house, the number of rooms, the size of the land, etc. The same is true of animation. The bigger the series, the more it costs to build.
Animation can be expensive. For example, Frozen II cost $1 million per minute of animation. But our goal is to keep production costs under $9500 per minute.
We plan to raise $50,000 to be used to develop new animated characters for the series, develop the world they live in, and then produce the first two episodes of My Life is Worth Living. We will then share these new episodes with global organizations who have the power to help us find the funding to produce a library of episodes.
 
The Production Plan
Your contribution will help take the series from the development stage all the way to the finished episodes. You can help us build this house! Here’s what the production process will look like:
Development:

We will create a library of characters
We will develop the world they live in while keeping social and cultural considerations in mind based on the statistics of teen suicide
We will create a series bible that will be reviewed by our suicide prevention experts to ensure that they align with best practices
We will write a treatment and script for each episode

Pre-Production:

2D artists will create designs for each character
Storyboard artists will create storyboards as a scene by scene road-map for each episode
We will collaborate with a casting director to cast the right voice talent
Editors will combine storyboards with voice over to create an animatic for each episode
We will do test screenings with teenagers and prevention experts 
We will use feedback from our test screenings to make improvements in order to create the best episodes possible

Production:

Animators will create animation libraries for each character
2D artists will design and create props for each character
2D artists will design and create backgrounds for each scene
Animators will animate each character in each scene

Post-Production:

Editors will composite the animation with the backgrounds and props
Editors will create any visual effects needed to help tell each story
A composer will score and sound design the episode to enhance the world
Editors will combine the soundtrack with the scenes to complete the episodes

 
Stretch Goal
If the campaign reaches the goal and receives additional donations, that money will be used to produce additional episodes. Our hope is to create 10 episodes dedicated to self-help and 10 episodes dedicated to helping others. Anything raised past our initial fundraising goal, will go toward that larger endeavor!
 
The Team

Wonder Media is a mission-driven animation studio that is working with my foundation to produce My Life is Worth Living. Led by Terry Thoren and Ryan Cannon, Wonder Media is known for producing animation that has the power to change children’s lives. I approached them after the series they produced for the Barbara Sinatra Children’s Center Foundation reached over 200 million people worldwide. Terry Thoren is the former CEO of the company that produced Rugrats and The Wild Thornberrys. He has over 40 years of animation industry experience, and he has spent the last decade with Ryan creating animations with a purpose.

Dr. James Mazza and Dr. Jennifer Stuber are the suicide prevention experts on our team. Dr. Mazza has been a suicide researcher and expert for over twenty years—focusing specifically on teen suicide and the ways in which suicide can be prevented. Dr. Stuber has personal experience with suicide and now passionately works with University of Washington’s Forefront—a suicide prevention organization. Drs. Stuber and Mazza will ensure that the series is research-based with proven strategies for suicide prevention.
 
Our team has the power to be successful. But without your support, we will not be able to reach the millions of teens who will benefit from the lessons we will provide to them. No one can do it alone! Be a part of My Life Is Worth Living today.
***
 
Response to Animation:
Content below was taken directly from YouTube comments & hand-written letters in response to the Barbara Sinatra Children's Center Foundation series mentioned above. Formatting and spelling will vary.

Child #1 -- “I was child abused and I’m nine I’m sad my mom said to not tell anybody but hey this is a video about telling the truth and tell a parent and I did.”
 

Child #2 --“My name is Julia i got sexually abuse from my trusted person, My uncle he always come and visit dad and give me Xbox,ipad,phone he gave me everything i wanted but when months past hes starting to be..too touchy and i think that was fine and when he visit dad he would always hug me and, I feel like something was touching my boobs.. but i tho it was an accident and other months came when it was about my birthday i was on my bed drawing some cool animes and he came and give me presents he told me its advance presents, And he lock the door and did something i didin’t want too i wanna scream but i’m afride i felt so horrable from myself and gross to myself i wanna tell my parents but i was afride that i’ll break my family, I cant hardly sleep it was so hard cause i keep on thinking about it and i lost my friend, I just suddenly scream at them when i saw this about 6 weeks ago i told my dad.. and i want to share too you im 13 now and i was touch when i was 8 my uncle got arrested and.. i keep telling on myself why didin’t i just told my parents i wouldn’t have to face this on 4 years of my whole life. You made me feel better thank you {Fight Child Abuse}"
Child #3 -- “I would like to thank you for making such a great video. This is what pushed me to finally report my abuser. It took a lot of guts but I kept remembering how this video said that the abuse would stop after I reported it. I knew things would get better. I find it interesting that as we near the end of the year, its coming to the time where one year ago I reported that monster, and this video popped up in my recommended. Things are happier for me now, and its all thanks to you guys. I know you will probably never see this, but I write this in hopes that you do, and to anybody who is being abused, PLEASE report it. Even if you aren’t sure about whether or not its considered abuse, you should always report it to somebody who will take it seriously. Because most of the time it IS abuse.﻿”
Child #4 -- “please make more vids they help me. My life is hard. My dad is like that to me he abuses me and hits me and break things please your my only hope﻿”

story:
Story

Kevin and Mark, who document their journey of owning a comedy club in NOLA.  What are the obstacles they encounter? Who are the various people that they come across as they navigate the task of hiring the right people?  Who are the family members that volunteer to step in and help them? 

Kevin McLin Jr Bio

Kevin McLin Jr. is an actor, screenwriter and film producer. Born and raised in New Orleans, Louisiana, Kevin attended Dillard University obtaining a Bachelor’s Degree in Mass Communications/Theater. Thereafter, he earned his Master’s Degree in Entertainment Business from Full Sail University. After completing his education, Kevin teamed up with his classmates to take a chance at the entertainment industry. Distributed by his production company, McLin Entertainment Company of America (MECA), Kevin wrote, produced and acted in his first independent feature film, The Station.

Mark Caesar Bio

Former member of The United States Air Force and a two term war veteran, Mark Caesar has been a breath of fresh air to the New Orleans comedy scene. Before Caesar took the internet by storm with his "Shit New Orleans Girls Say video", which today has millions of views and was filmed and directed by Steve Wade (Dubb Productions) Mark was already playing large audiences across the United States. With his unique joke writing and awkward delivery of punchlines Caesar hangs his hat on never being compared to another comedian! In 2012 Mark was a winner in the Louisiana funniest person competition and appeared in the hit comedy movie "This is the End" along side comedic genius Seth Rogan and James Franco. In 2011 Caesar decided that New Orleans comedy needed a voice so he founded Piss Yo Pants Comedy LLC. Also that same  year Mark started his weekly comedy series "Laugh And Sip" where many of the nations best comedians from the south stopped by to hone their skills where at  any given time Caesar could yell out "Don't trip!" And the capacity crowd would respond "Laugh And Sip". In 2015 Mark embarked on his national "This Ain't No Open Mic Comedy Tour" where he witnessed sold out shows in New York, Atlanta, New Orleans, Toronto, Washington, D.C., and Oakland amongst other cites. Also in 2015 Caesar headlined 97 Comedy shows gaining the rep as a tour monster!

How to Help

On social media: post and repost on Instagram, Twitter and Facebook. Tell your family and friends to get them to help. Talk about it at work and share the link to everyone you know who wants to support someone’s dreams.

Funding

Our fundraiser goal is $50k, to lock down locations, pay/feed the crew and actors along with equipment rentals and executing the marketing plan. Two weeks prior to the release date of “Comedy Club”,  the marketing plan will go into effect to reach our target audience.

story:
Who Are We?

THE FEMALE GAZE, is made by a team of female filmmakers and alumni from Emerson College. Shefali Vasudevan, the creator, wanted to create a show that explored the stories of her friends and life in Los Angeles--with a specific emphasis on telling these stories through the female perspective.

This campaign would raise funds for the costs of production, post-production, and marketing, that were originally self-funded in the first season. This includes camera costs, equipment rental, food, and much more listed below in more detail and in the above video.

 

 

“I was so tired of not seeing a representation of myself in TV Shows and Movies. I also was growing restless at my day job and wanted to create something that I thought was meaningful and people could relate to--and that’s how The Female Gaze was born” - Shefali

 

 

Above is a breakdown of where your money would be going towards! We decided to do Flex Funding because even if we don’t reach our entire goal, Season Two will still be made. We’ve got a plan B, C, and D to make sure this project reaches fruition, but we could definitely use your help to get the ball rolling.

For Perks we are offering a digital download of the series, Female Gaze swag, an executive producer credit and much more listed on the side!

 

 

You can help us in all sorts of ways! Quite possibly the biggest way you can help us is by helping us spread the word about the series. The entire Season 1 is out now on YouTube so check it out share and subscribe! (YouTube Link) We also have links to our Season 1 Trailer and International Women's Day Promo above.

 

You can also follow us on social media: Instagram, Facebook, and Twitter.

story:
Hi, I'm Caleb Smiley

I'm an award winning filmmaker and  I'm passionate about telling powerful stories that involve great characters.

This campaign is to help jump start  my passion project. Ever since High School I have had the idea to tell a story about my experience in church Youth Group. I have learned a lot from my positive and negative experiences and I want to share them in a fun and  entertaining way.

Funding this campaign will get this project off the ground and prove the merit of this project to potential investors. The goal is to make a short trailer showing powerful highlights from the first couple episodes so we can show the style feel and humor of the show.

What We Need & What You Get

The funds from this campaign will allow us to deliver a professional level of quality to the production. The money will be used to pay professional crew members like the director of Photography and Audio/sound engineer. It will also help cover the cost of equipment needed for the shoot.  Any extra money will go back  into the project and will allow us to more easily move forward by being able to purchase things like a solid editing computer and other essential gear.

For those that donate, we offer multiple levels of personal updates and communication about the project. We will keep you updated with emails and possibly schedule some q&a live streams so we can talk about our next steps.

If we don't end up reaching our goal, we will still try to make the trailer video but won't be able to do so with the ideal amount of resources.

The Impact

If you are a christian, you know and feel the need for family friendly content that is devoid of political agendas. Unfortunately there are very few alternatives that are also well made and entertaining with solid storytelling. This show will be one that all people can enjoy. There will be no heavy handed christian theology but the story will be echoing God and biblical ideals all throughout. We want to make something that Christians and non-Christians alike can enjoy. We want to make people laugh but will also tackle some very heavy issues and show what happens when you make the right and wrong choices. We strongly believe this show has the capacity to change lives.

Getting the show off the ground will have major challenges. Our first season will require a couple million to produce but I have little doubt it can be done. This has always been a strong calling for me and I believe that if it is God's will for this show to be made then there is nothing that will stand in our way. I won't lie to you and tell you this isn't a crazy idea for someone like me to make this happen, I have never made a TV show before or any Hollywood level production at all but I see our situation as no different than David or Moses or Saul or Peter or Joseph or Gideon or any of the many characters in scripture that were the lowest of the low. The thing is that God's power is made perfect in weakness and if this show is meant to happen then it's God's power that will make it happen.

Other Ways You Can Help

We need help in so many ways and there's more that we need besides money.  If you want to support what we are doing here please pray for us and for God's will to be done for this project. Please also tell anyone else you think would want to hear about this project and direct them to this page.  You can also follow us on Facebook  https://www.facebook.com/The-Youth-Group-103474...

God Bless!

story:
In this test scene, Kenolta Lyef, a street-talking, potbellied, alcoholic knight on the animal-populated planet of Planimus, has been arrested for the assassination of President Kaprakoza, a goat. He is accused of rigging the planet’s Globe of Peace and rolling it over the chief executive, flattening him. His monogrammed flask is discovered at the scene of the crime. The police detain Kenolta and try to get a confession out of him by any means necessary.

This scene is from Space Rabbit - a puppet sci-fi TV show directed by filmmaker and critic Matt Zoller Seitz. It's an adventure about a group of puppet animals trying to free their planet from a dictator. In production now. Release in 2018.

*

3/28/17 Update

Once the campaign ends we will contact all donors in early April re: perks fulfillment (getting items for the capsule reviews, etc).  Thanks!

*

Amazing New Perk!  Guillermo del Toro book SIGNED and PERSONALIZED by the author/Guillermo del Toro!

For a $100 donation.  See Perks on right side of the page for more info.

*

New Perk!  10 Space Rabbit Thank You Cards by Emily Flake for a $25 donation

$25.  These Space Rabbit Thank You Cards contain original art work created for Space Rabbit project by New Yorker magazine cartoonist Emily Flake.  Flake's work has also appeared in The New York Times and many other publications.  10 folded cards - 5.47" x 4.21" size, with envelopes, included in this perk.

*

New Perk!  Capsule review by MZS

$20.  Matt will write a one-paragraph review of any movie, television series, painting or photograph that the donor requests.  These reviews will be posted on the Space Rabbit website, indicating that they were a part of the crowdfunding campaign.  If you are asking MZS to review something you made, you'll have to agree not to use it to advertise your project.  

*

BIG NEWS FROM 3/2/17 Thu - see more in Updates

*

SPACE RABBIT, a science fiction adventure starring puppets and stuffed animals

 

Matt and Kenolta

My name is Matt Zoller Seitz. I've been a film and TV critic and independent filmmaker for 20 years, but my whole life, I secretly wanted to be Jim Henson. My two children were raised in a version of the world I'd like to inhabit, one filled with eccentric stuffed animal and puppet characters that have psychologies as complex as any human's. The star of this world was Eta P. Squirrel, a rodent born in Kentucky who remade herself as a wisecracking New York dame. Supporting characters included Dusty Rabbit, who was dumb as a carrot but loyal to his friends; Senor Kitty, a dashing Chilean alley cat who dressed like Cary Grant and prized dignity above all else; and Margareta von Colada, a Siamese cat whose acting ability would dazzle Meryl Streep. These performers and more will appear in Space Rabbit. 

SPACE RABBIT is the first film project for this group of tiny but passionate puppet actors: an epic tale of conspiracy, in which a band of unlikely heroes tries to prevent their humble republic from falling into a dictator's paws. Some scenes will be shot on miniature sets, which will then be used as rear-screen projected backdrops for the puppets.  Other scenes will be shot on full size, hand puppet-scale sets, half the size of human soundstages.  But the style will always be gloriously cinematic, treating these handmade settings and characters as if they were existing worlds shot by the crew of an epic that expected to sweep the Oscars. The story includes a number of elaborate action scenes, constructed for maximum suspense even though they might end with, say, a duck dropping a toy piano on an elephant's head.

Behind the scenes shot, from February test scene filming: Kenolta is interrogated by a menacing boar detective

Character drawing by puppet designer Heather Piper

 

What do we need to make SPACE RABBIT?

We are raising money to make the pilot episode of season 1 of Space Rabbit.  This project started off as a feature length film, then we realized that there are so many amazing characters and scenes that the story is best told as at least an 8 episode television show.  We hope to create a mesmerizing pilot episode and then convince a TV distributor or network to fund the rest of the season.  If that plan doesn't come to fruition, we may either finish season 1 on our own using means available to us and then try to self distribute it, perhaps through internet Video on Demand, DVD, Blu Ray; or we may integrate what we've shot into a self-contained feature film, then send the film to festivals, seek distribution, or self-distribute.

SPACE RABBIT needs your donations to bring this story to life, put it on screens of all kinds and sizes, and most importantly, to entertain.

We need funds to design and build original puppet characters—in some cases whole armies of characters—and construct the world they inhabit: everything from a jazz club, a swanky bachelor pad, and a decadent throne room to animal- and food-shaped hovercrafts, dense city skylines, and spectacular landscapes. These will have to be built from wood, paper, plastic,  discarded appliances and office supplies, and perhaps furniture we rescued from city dumps and our parents' garages (everything is raw material as far as we're concerned). And of course we will need to pay for professional puppeteers, voice actors, camera and lighting equipment, and food for the cast and crew during the summer 2017 filming period.

Part of the money raised will be set aside to promote and distribute Space Rabbit and get it out in front of people who will love it - especially if  we end up having to self-distribute the project. If we end up self-distributing on internet VOD, we will use the distribution funds to create an effective marketing campaign, and creating home video versions of the project; high quality DVDs and Blu-Rays.  

Daniel Guillaro filming the test scene

If the project's ultimate form ends up being a movie, we might need to create a high-quality version of Space Rabbit that can be screened at film festivals, then pay for the festival admission fees and travel expenses. We would also need to pay for online and other marketing, DVDs and Blu-rays, and theatrical screenings for critics and distributors.

We will work towards getting the best deals possible on work space rental, storage, puppets, sets, voice actors, film equipment and crew, editing, sound recording and music. 

Once the project is done, we will tell donors how the money was spent.

Matt at rehearsal with puppeteers Eric Wright (operating the lion), Rachel Schapira (operating the small pig) and Chris Palmieri (the wild boar).

 

What do you get if you donate to SPACE RABBIT?

NOTE: When a perk says "movie" re: Space Rabbit, we mean the show/TV show.  Earlier descriptions of project got locked in once donors claimed a given perk, cannot be edited after that point.

For starters, a story like no other: exciting, funny and visually rich. The exact delivery date of the home video and digital downloads versions of Space Rabbit will depend on the distribution life, deadlines, limitations of the project. At present, we expect it to be finished and ready to show in fall, 2018.

Beyond that, you'll get to choose from a variety of perks. You could choose a signed edition of one of my books on film and TV (I have a few that are autographed by both myself and Wes Anderson or Oliver Stone). You could assign me to write an essay on the film or TV program of your choice. Or you could have me interview you about a work, or a life experience, that had a profound effect on you, then turn that into the sort of profile that you'd read in a magazine.

You can also receive a voice mail message from one of the puppet characters as a perk - personalized voice mail thank you message from one of the characters, performed by the actor.

The actual puppet characters used in Space Rabbit are available as perks. They're magnificent creations made by skilled puppet designers. Based on your donation level, we will select one or more of the puppet characters, a copy that we will build specially for you, and ship them to you along with a personal thank you from me. These are not stuffed animals or sock puppets, but fully articulated "hero" puppets, similar to the puppets in the test scene above, that are of sufficiently high quality to anchor a movie or TV show.

 

The Task Ahead & Why We Need Your Donations

I have a lot of experience making independent films and documentaries about film history and style, and I am surrounding myself with experienced performers and crew; puppeteers, production designers, set builders, cinematographers, editors and sound experts. The show is produced by Sujewa Ekanayake, who produced the test scene at the top of this page and have produced six features and many other film and video projects, and owns and blogs at the well-ranked independent film blog DIY Filmmaker.  The show's co-writer and editor, Steven Santos, is a 20-year veteran of the television industry, and has edited programs for Discovery, A&E, Home & Garden Television, MTV and other networks.

Matt, Kenolta, Sujewa Ekanayake, Steven Santos

Steven editing

Our amazing puppets will be built by a talented team led by Chris Palmieri and Heather Piper - experienced puppet builders and puppeteers from NYC.

Chris Palmieri and one of his puppet creations

One of Heather Piper's creations

 Our set design team is led by Rachel Schapira - a very creative and experienced NYC artist.  

Rachel Schapira discusses a set design with Matt

Award winning composer John Califra will create a sweeping original score for Space Rabbit, in the vein of classic orchestral scores from 1940s movies.  

Matt, Kenolta, Chris, and composer John Califra

During the fundraising campaign in March we will highlight other members of our talented creative team.

Based on our experiences on previous projects and our experience with the test scene above, we feel confident that we will be able create a polished, satisfying TV show pilot episode  - containing custom built puppets and sets - at a low budget independent film type budget.

That said, due to the epic scale of this project, this is a case where every dollar truly makes a difference. We are creating an entire universe, and although the intimate, hand-made nature of the project is part of its charm, we want this thing to be as ridiculous and amazing as possible. A few extra thousand dollars in the budget could mean the difference between a battle scene that features a dozen puppets and no pyrotechnics or vehicles to one that rivals a Marvel or Star Wars film in its sheer visual excess. A hundred-dollar donation, for example, will buy me two additional groundhog warriors that will be used in the battle sequence that ends the pilot, a bloody puppet clash modeled on Stanley Kubrick's Paths of Glory. This show will feel big regardless; the question is just how big we can make it look?

That's where you come in.

What other ways can you help?

Even if you can't contribute money, you can help us by telling people about the Space Rabbit IndieGoGo campaign, recommending our Facebook and Twitter pages, and sharing the many photos and sketches and behind-the-scenes videos and puppet character videos that we will post during the fundraising period.  All assistance is greatly appreciated.

Thank you for helping to make my dream project a reality.  And thank you for becoming a part of the Space Rabbit universe!

MORE NEWS, PHOTOS, VIDEO, TEAM MEMBER INTERVIEWS & PROFILES COMING SOON!
story_txt:
In this test scene, Kenolta Lyef, a street-talking, potbellied, alcoholic knight on the animal-populated planet of Planimus, has been arrested for the assassination of President Kaprakoza, a goat. He is accused of rigging the planet’s Globe of Peace and rolling it over the chief executive, flattening him. His monogrammed flask is discovered at the scene of the crime. The police detain Kenolta and try to get a confession out of him by any means necessary.
This scene is from Space Rabbit - a puppet sci-fi TV show directed by filmmaker and critic Matt Zoller Seitz. It's an adventure about a group of puppet animals trying to free their planet from a dictator. In production now. Release in 2018.
*
3/28/17 Update
Once the campaign ends we will contact all donors in early April re: perks fulfillment (getting items for the capsule reviews, etc).  Thanks!
*
Amazing New Perk!  Guillermo del Toro book SIGNED and PERSONALIZED by the author/Guillermo del Toro! 
For a $100 donation.  See Perks on right side of the page for more info.

*
New Perk!  10 Space Rabbit Thank You Cards by Emily Flake for a $25 donation

$25.  These Space Rabbit Thank You Cards contain original art work created for Space Rabbit project by New Yorker magazine cartoonist Emily Flake.  Flake's work has also appeared in The New York Times and many other publications.  10 folded cards - 5.47" x 4.21" size, with envelopes, included in this perk.
*
New Perk!  Capsule review by MZS

$20.  Matt will write a one-paragraph review of any movie, television series, painting or photograph that the donor requests.  These reviews will be posted on the Space Rabbit website, indicating that they were a part of the crowdfunding campaign.  If you are asking MZS to review something you made, you'll have to agree not to use it to advertise your project.  
*
BIG NEWS FROM 3/2/17 Thu - see more in Updates

*
SPACE RABBIT, a science fiction adventure starring puppets and stuffed animals
 

Matt and Kenolta
My name is Matt Zoller Seitz. I've been a film and TV critic and independent filmmaker for 20 years, but my whole life, I secretly wanted to be Jim Henson. My two children were raised in a version of the world I'd like to inhabit, one filled with eccentric stuffed animal and puppet characters that have psychologies as complex as any human's. The star of this world was Eta P. Squirrel, a rodent born in Kentucky who remade herself as a wisecracking New York dame. Supporting characters included Dusty Rabbit, who was dumb as a carrot but loyal to his friends; Senor Kitty, a dashing Chilean alley cat who dressed like Cary Grant and prized dignity above all else; and Margareta von Colada, a Siamese cat whose acting ability would dazzle Meryl Streep. These performers and more will appear in Space Rabbit. 

SPACE RABBIT is the first film project for this group of tiny but passionate puppet actors: an epic tale of conspiracy, in which a band of unlikely heroes tries to prevent their humble republic from falling into a dictator's paws. Some scenes will be shot on miniature sets, which will then be used as rear-screen projected backdrops for the puppets.  Other scenes will be shot on full size, hand puppet-scale sets, half the size of human soundstages.  But the style will always be gloriously cinematic, treating these handmade settings and characters as if they were existing worlds shot by the crew of an epic that expected to sweep the Oscars. The story includes a number of elaborate action scenes, constructed for maximum suspense even though they might end with, say, a duck dropping a toy piano on an elephant's head.

Behind the scenes shot, from February test scene filming: Kenolta is interrogated by a menacing boar detective


Character drawing by puppet designer Heather Piper
 
What do we need to make SPACE RABBIT?
We are raising money to make the pilot episode of season 1 of Space Rabbit.  This project started off as a feature length film, then we realized that there are so many amazing characters and scenes that the story is best told as at least an 8 episode television show.  We hope to create a mesmerizing pilot episode and then convince a TV distributor or network to fund the rest of the season.  If that plan doesn't come to fruition, we may either finish season 1 on our own using means available to us and then try to self distribute it, perhaps through internet Video on Demand, DVD, Blu Ray; or we may integrate what we've shot into a self-contained feature film, then send the film to festivals, seek distribution, or self-distribute.
SPACE RABBIT needs your donations to bring this story to life, put it on screens of all kinds and sizes, and most importantly, to entertain.
We need funds to design and build original puppet characters—in some cases whole armies of characters—and construct the world they inhabit: everything from a jazz club, a swanky bachelor pad, and a decadent throne room to animal- and food-shaped hovercrafts, dense city skylines, and spectacular landscapes. These will have to be built from wood, paper, plastic,  discarded appliances and office supplies, and perhaps furniture we rescued from city dumps and our parents' garages (everything is raw material as far as we're concerned). And of course we will need to pay for professional puppeteers, voice actors, camera and lighting equipment, and food for the cast and crew during the summer 2017 filming period.
Part of the money raised will be set aside to promote and distribute Space Rabbit and get it out in front of people who will love it - especially if  we end up having to self-distribute the project. If we end up self-distributing on internet VOD, we will use the distribution funds to create an effective marketing campaign, and creating home video versions of the project; high quality DVDs and Blu-Rays.  

Daniel Guillaro filming the test scene
If the project's ultimate form ends up being a movie, we might need to create a high-quality version of Space Rabbit that can be screened at film festivals, then pay for the festival admission fees and travel expenses. We would also need to pay for online and other marketing, DVDs and Blu-rays, and theatrical screenings for critics and distributors.
We will work towards getting the best deals possible on work space rental, storage, puppets, sets, voice actors, film equipment and crew, editing, sound recording and music. 
Once the project is done, we will tell donors how the money was spent.

Matt at rehearsal with puppeteers Eric Wright (operating the lion), Rachel Schapira (operating the small pig) and Chris Palmieri (the wild boar).
 
What do you get if you donate to SPACE RABBIT? 
NOTE: When a perk says "movie" re: Space Rabbit, we mean the show/TV show.  Earlier descriptions of project got locked in once donors claimed a given perk, cannot be edited after that point.
For starters, a story like no other: exciting, funny and visually rich. The exact delivery date of the home video and digital downloads versions of Space Rabbit will depend on the distribution life, deadlines, limitations of the project. At present, we expect it to be finished and ready to show in fall, 2018.
Beyond that, you'll get to choose from a variety of perks. You could choose a signed edition of one of my books on film and TV (I have a few that are autographed by both myself and Wes Anderson or Oliver Stone). You could assign me to write an essay on the film or TV program of your choice. Or you could have me interview you about a work, or a life experience, that had a profound effect on you, then turn that into the sort of profile that you'd read in a magazine.

You can also receive a voice mail message from one of the puppet characters as a perk - personalized voice mail thank you message from one of the characters, performed by the actor.
The actual puppet characters used in Space Rabbit are available as perks. They're magnificent creations made by skilled puppet designers. Based on your donation level, we will select one or more of the puppet characters, a copy that we will build specially for you, and ship them to you along with a personal thank you from me. These are not stuffed animals or sock puppets, but fully articulated "hero" puppets, similar to the puppets in the test scene above, that are of sufficiently high quality to anchor a movie or TV show.


 
The Task Ahead & Why We Need Your Donations
I have a lot of experience making independent films and documentaries about film history and style, and I am surrounding myself with experienced performers and crew; puppeteers, production designers, set builders, cinematographers, editors and sound experts. The show is produced by Sujewa Ekanayake, who produced the test scene at the top of this page and have produced six features and many other film and video projects, and owns and blogs at the well-ranked independent film blog DIY Filmmaker.  The show's co-writer and editor, Steven Santos, is a 20-year veteran of the television industry, and has edited programs for Discovery, A&E, Home & Garden Television, MTV and other networks.

Matt, Kenolta, Sujewa Ekanayake, Steven Santos

Steven editing
Our amazing puppets will be built by a talented team led by Chris Palmieri and Heather Piper - experienced puppet builders and puppeteers from NYC.

Chris Palmieri and one of his puppet creations

One of Heather Piper's creations
 Our set design team is led by Rachel Schapira - a very creative and experienced NYC artist.  


Rachel Schapira discusses a set design with Matt
Award winning composer John Califra will create a sweeping original score for Space Rabbit, in the vein of classic orchestral scores from 1940s movies.  

Matt, Kenolta, Chris, and composer John Califra
During the fundraising campaign in March we will highlight other members of our talented creative team.
Based on our experiences on previous projects and our experience with the test scene above, we feel confident that we will be able create a polished, satisfying TV show pilot episode  - containing custom built puppets and sets - at a low budget independent film type budget.
That said, due to the epic scale of this project, this is a case where every dollar truly makes a difference. We are creating an entire universe, and although the intimate, hand-made nature of the project is part of its charm, we want this thing to be as ridiculous and amazing as possible. A few extra thousand dollars in the budget could mean the difference between a battle scene that features a dozen puppets and no pyrotechnics or vehicles to one that rivals a Marvel or Star Wars film in its sheer visual excess. A hundred-dollar donation, for example, will buy me two additional groundhog warriors that will be used in the battle sequence that ends the pilot, a bloody puppet clash modeled on Stanley Kubrick's Paths of Glory. This show will feel big regardless; the question is just how big we can make it look?
That's where you come in.

What other ways can you help?
Even if you can't contribute money, you can help us by telling people about the Space Rabbit IndieGoGo campaign, recommending our Facebook and Twitter pages, and sharing the many photos and sketches and behind-the-scenes videos and puppet character videos that we will post during the fundraising period.  All assistance is greatly appreciated.
Thank you for helping to make my dream project a reality.  And thank you for becoming a part of the Space Rabbit universe!MORE NEWS, PHOTOS, VIDEO, TEAM MEMBER INTERVIEWS & PROFILES COMING SOON!

story:
Over The Counter Motto: I love a drug store. Whether a candy bar or a drug, there’s always something to make you feel good in a pharmacy.

 Over The Counter is about an idealistic med student slumming it as a pharmacy technician in a quirky, independent pharmacy, in the small town of Greenville, but soon he finds that irresistible girl behind the bench can fill his prescription for love over the counter. This campaign is raising funds to shoot the pilot episode of Over The Counter written by David Letendre. 

 Over The Counter is a sitcom that I've been developing for many years now. It's based on my experiences working in both retail and independent pharmacies, as well as building and consulting in the pharmacy industry for over twenty five years. The characters in this pilot are fictional, but most of them are based on real people.

 We want to show a very positive view of life in a pharmacy, along with all its craziness. It's about family, community and helping others. Most pharmacists have a great sense of humor and customers really do love them. They are the number two most trusted profession, behind nurses, and are the unsung heroes of the medical profession. 

 We need funding to build sets, rent costumes, hire actors and cover post-production costs. We plan to present this pilot to distributors and television networks in order to get this show on the air. My goal is to keep the assembled cast together and I hope you will donate generously to our campaign.

story:
My name is Dan Gottlieb, and I created I AM OMEGA to tell the story of a tortured guardian angel who has watched humanity destroy itself and has had enough.

The year 1914 sets the stage for Omega's path of destruction.

I started this project in 2018. I was at a point in my life where I've started to get tired of everything. I needed things to change. Then I thought what if there was a character that just had enough...too much to bear anymore.

What would you do?

I am a Brooklyn native, illustrator, and costume actor who previously worked for DC Comics in the 1990's. I have worked at various other companies as an artist and designer through the years. I've had a background performing Off Broadway as well as voice over work in various cartoons and other media. More recently, I have worked with the fallen officers fund and local children’s hospitals while dressed as two of Marvel’s finest: Captain America and Iron Man!

I've applied my background in storytelling to bring the world of I am Omega to life. I created, designed, illustrated and developed the story for this concept. 

 

SUBSCRIBE to our channel on YouTube The players group films. This is where the episode in its completion would be broadcast. It has the attention of a few networks. Updates will be on this page as we go.

Your help on this project is appreciated!

By contributing to this project you will see the amazing world that I am Omega is and we can animate the expanded universe by hiring in top of line animators and voice talent.

We already have some amazing actors attached to the project such as

Laura Aguinaga as Amanda Crawford (Shades of Blue, VH-1 The Breaks & Ray Donovan)

Michael Mulligan as Gabriel (NBC Universal, Marvel Appearance & designer at Jim Henson Studios)

Mike Wring as Uriel (Doctor Who, Gangs of London & Upcoming: Unspecified Marvel Project)

Meaghan Bloom Fluitt as Sealtiel (Sweetbitter, My Crazy Love &  Upcoming: The Exodite)

and many more!

By contributing to this campaign we are bringing an amazing world of characters to life. This story shows how cool angels can be. Being faithful to the lore while showing them in a brand new epic light! ​This story also reflects what is going on in the world. It is relatable and not specific to one audience.

Your Contribution

The reason for the campaign is simple. I am just one guy! 

To date, I have created all the content, drawn every line, and animated every frame and this project deserves a team of animators and sound engineers to step in and really bring it to life! This expansive and imaginative story can not be told in its current incarnation and needs funding to get it to its proper level of detail and design.

To be blunt, I need your help 

 

You are critical to us and the continued work in the arts

 By contributing to this project you will see the amazing world that “I am Omega” is, and with your help we will be able to animate the expanded universe by hiring in top of line animators and voice talent. 

This means jobs for the talented people who need it.

You can also help us by sharing this campaign on Facebook, Instagram, TikTok and so on.

We know that with what is going on in the world times are hard. So you would help us immensely by getting the word out and getting those who can help to contribute.

 

THANK YOU!

 

OH YEAH WE HAVE STRETCH GOALS!

75K EVERYONE GETS AN EXCLUSIVE PRINT WITH NEW ARTWORK.

100K WE WILL MAKE A SPECIAL SET OF TRADING CARDS OF THE ARCHANGELS ADDED TO EVERY CONTRIBUTION ABOVE $250.00

150K EVERYONE GETS A LUCIFER TEE SHIRT ADDED WITH THEIR CONTRIBUTION OF $30.00 OR MORE.

 

 

The story

 

Laura can't sleep, she has horrible dreams about an angel who sees destruction on his watch. They are linked somehow. Laura finally gains access to her full dream memory which tells Omega's entire life. There is one moment in his existence that sets him specifically on his dark path.

The moment was.....The year 1914.

 

We are approaching a series of Networks about making this a series.

For more information about this project contact Dan Gottlieb: iamomega@mail.com the subject 1914.

Created by Dan Gottlieb

VOICE ACTORS

Amanda Crawford - Laura Aguinaga @lauraaguinaga1251

Omega & The Principalities - Dan Gottlieb

Guardian Angel Evan - Owen Davis

Archangel Michael - Michael T Davis

Archangel Sealitel -Meaghan Bloom Fluitt

Archangel Jegudiel & Metatron - Edward Ng

Script & Editing:  Dan Gottlieb & Thomas Casbarrow

Original Art, Animation & Story Direction

SPECIAL THANKS: Connie Lee, Michael Lora,  Andrew Gordon, Orlando Santiago, Joseph Heintz & The Print House

story:
We need your help! A Piece of Art is more than a TV show, we’re a team project of more than 50+ students collaborating to create a passionate and truly fantastic program. By supporting our project, you’re directly contributing to the progress of our collaboration.

Our names are Brittney Cooper, Kyle Friedman, and Jake Orloff, we’re film/photography students at Ithaca College and the creators of A Piece of Art. This show is more than a pet project to us, it’s the goal of simultaneously creating a feelgood comedy while fostering an educational environment for film students. We hope you’ll read on and enjoy what we have to offer!

 

A Piece of Art - The Rundown

 

Have you ever seen a blank portrait being sold for $413,000 and said, “who would buy that?”

Or sat through your middle schooler’s improv performance and thought, “whose parents let them do that?”

And surely you’ve seen the occasional viral video of a runway model showing off a dress made of graham crackers and you’ve just thought, “why?”

 

A Piece of Art seeks to answer these deeply philosophical questions about art. Our mockumentary follows three high school artists competing for an art scholarship to the University of Louisville—A cult-indoctrinated painter, a sellout actress, and a completely uncoordinated fashion designer race to create their pieces of art.

A Piece of Art airs on Ithaca College Television (ICTV), a renowned college television channel that has won plenty of accolades. If you want to see the Spring 2021 line-up or watch more programs from ICTV, visit ICTV.org.

 

Our Perks & Goals

When we first stepped foot into college, we noticed a trend: a broadening gap between experienced upperclassmen and impassioned underclassmen, but not many bridges in between. That’s why, since we developed the idea for A Piece of Art, our main goal was to bring these two groups closer together and foster a learning environment. We’ve been in production since December 2019 and we are proud of the steps we’ve taken to achieve our ambitions.

After successful pre-production, our community would love to bring this story to life and we can’t do it without your contribution. Every single donation received will go into our budget for the safety and quality of our production, and we cannot thank you enough for it. That’s why we want to return the favor! Here are a few perks you can receive for contributing to our campaign:

•Personal Thank-You Note! - We appreciate you so much, maybe we’ll dot our i’s with hearts.

•An A Piece of Art Laptop Sticker! - You can put it on other things too, we won’t tattle.

•Behind-The-Scenes Footage! - If we catch someone drop ice cream on their pants on film, you can bet you’ll be the first to watch.

•The Full, Uncut Episodes! - Spoil the extra parts to your coworkers in the office kitchen and watch everyone get mad at you.

•And more! - That’s right, we went nonspecific on you. Check out our tiers for more info!

 

Our financial goal seems like a pretty penny, but filmmaking is anything but cheap. It’s important you know where your money’s going, so we’ve laid out our budget for you.

•Health Safety: We pledged to provide hand sanitizer, disposable masks/gloves, and disinfectant on all our sets this spring. We take the critical issue of COVID-19 extremely seriously, and you can find our safety plan farther down.

•Equipment: As hard as we can try, it would be ambitious to create a TV show without a camera. We’re raising funds to obtain better equipment to present our story to you with our best foot forward.

•Props/Location: World-building is much harder than it seems. We tried a dry run without any props and locations and… well, it wasn’t great. That’s why our budget will also go to renting safe locations and constructing props.

•Food for Cast/Crew: You should see a film set before lunch and compare it to a film set after lunch. Considering all the hard work our cast and crew dedicates to the show, this is crucial.

 

A Small Note

It’s not like college students to ask for money… cough... but we want to reiterate how important to us your contributions are. Whether you’re here to donate, share with friends, or DM to Tiger Woods (which reminds us, please DM this campaign to Tiger Woods), we cannot express how much we appreciate your support. By taking time out of your day to read this, you’re helping us an incredible amount. Thank you, and we hope you’ll watch A Piece of Art after our production in Spring 2021!

 

Risks & Challenges

2020 has taught us that plans change. Events are canceled, postponed, accidentally reserved at landscaping companies instead of luxury hotels… That’s why we have prepared for the chance that school may revert to remote education. Because of this possibility, we are planning to finish filming our pilot only three weeks into production, postponing the production of the remaining five episodes to Fall 2021 if needed.

As stated earlier, we take the health of our cast and crew very seriously. Below, you can find a link to our COVID-19 safety protocol. We are filming in accordance with NY state’s production guidelines, and some of our policies have been summarized below.

•Filming with minimum cast/crew on set, 50% occupancy of every location.

•Disinfecting props and equipment between takes.

•Handling as much business remotely as possible.

Please take a minute to review our full document if you get a chance:

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1sVYbnbzZbq55gd...

 

How Else Can I Help?

There are lots of different ways to contribute to our campaign. Here are just a few:

•Know someone who’s interested in film/television, or might find this project interesting? Send the link to this campaign their way!

•Are you an Ithaca College student? We’re still looking for talented and eager members to join our community!

•@TigerWoods on Twitter about it. C’mon Tiger, notice us.

 

Got any questions or comments? We’d love to respond! Send them our way at APieceOfArt@ICTV.org. Thanks!
